Objectives: The aim of the study is to review the application of machine learning (ML) in improving accident prevention and to assess whether ML can reveal more than what is currently known about accidents in the construction industry.
Problem: The persistent issue of occupational accidents in the construction industry, despite efforts to eliminate them, is a significant challenge. The study seeks to understand if machine learning can provide better insights into accident causes and prevention, beyond current knowledge.
Data: The study is based on a systematic literature review of research that uses machine learning to analyze accident records in the construction industry, focusing on databases of collected registrations about causes and contexts of accidents.
Methods_Techniques: The study reviews the application of machine learning techniques such as prediction models, data mining, Natural Language Processing (NLP), and graph mining. It examines ML’s role in predicting accidents and identifying the causes of injuries, while also assessing the limitations and challenges in current ML methodologies.
Results: The review indicates that ML is beneficial for discovering associations between different features in accident data, but it is still at an early stage of development. Gaps exist in the justification of methodological choices, data processing, and external testing. The review suggests that future research should focus on improving testing accuracy, explaining methodological choices, merging data sources, and considering more attributes like risk management.

title: Application of artificial intelligence in electrical safety
authors: Doherty, Mike and Esmaeili, Behzad
objectives: As artificial intelligence (AI) becomes more sophisticated in imitating human cognitive processes (e.g., problem solving, object detection, and learni
problem: As artificial intelligence (AI) becomes more sophisticated in imitating human cognitive processes (e
abstract: As artificial intelligence (AI) becomes more sophisticated in imitating human cognitive processes (e.g., problem solving, object detection, and learning), it has transformed several industry sectors and has had a growing impact on the way construction projects are delivered. One of the areas that has great potential to advance breakthroughs for innovative improvements is in electrical safety. Data generated from images captured from mobile devices, unmanned aerial vehicles, wearable sensors, building information modeling (BIM), and others present an opportunity for construction safety professionals and in many other sectors to analyze and benefit from the insights generated from the data using AI, machine learning and deep learning systems. For example, AI-based algorithms can be used to scan images from jobsites for safety hazards, such as workers not wearing protective equipment, and correlate the images with accident records; identify unsafe worker behavior and suggest training and education priorities; or track the real-time interactions of workers, machinery, and objects on the site and alert supervisors of potential safety issues. Using AI to execute the existing Shock and Arc Flash Risk Assessment Procedure templates from CSA Z462 and NFPA 70E as real-world scenarios and the potential ethical factors from the workers perspectives will also be discussed. Considering AI's immense potential, this study aims to synthesize emerging trends of artificial intelligence in electrical safety.  © 2020 IEEE.
Objectives: The main objective of the study is to synthesize emerging trends of artificial intelligence in electrical safety.
Problem: The challenge addressed is the need to enhance safety measures in construction projects through the application of sophisticated AI technologies for monitoring and prevention purposes.
Data: The data used in the study include images captured from mobile devices, unmanned aerial vehicles, wearable sensors, and building information modeling (BIM).
Methods_Techniques: AI, machine learning, and deep learning systems were used to analyze the data. Specific techniques include scanning jobsite images for safety hazards, correlating images with accident records, identifying unsafe worker behavior, and tracking real-time interactions on construction sites.
Results: The study found that AI-based algorithms effectively monitor safety hazards, identify risks, and suggest preventive measures. It also discussed using AI to execute Shock and Arc Flash Risk Assessment Procedure templates and addressed potential ethical issues from worker perspectives.

title: Construction safety and health hazard awareness in Web of Science and Weibo between 1991 and 2021
authors: Zeng, Liyun and Li, Rita Yi Man
abstract: The construction industry is one of the most hazardous industries, and construction hazard awareness is a major concern and vital at work. This paper compared 11,829 construction safety and health hazard awareness Weibo microposts and 769 articles indexed in Web of Science (WoS) from 1900 to 2021. It compared different foci between academia and laypeople by studying safety hazards like fire, electrical, chemical, collapsing trenches, and health-related risks such as asbestos and heat stress. The first construction safety and health hazard paper was published in 1991 in WoS, while the first construction hazard awareness related Weibo microposts appeared in 2011. Safety Science is the journal that publishes most articles in this area, and the US is the most productive country. On the other hand, the top 5 Weibo microbloggers were government departments. Popular construction safety and health hazard Weibo topics included collapse, earthquake, safety management, risk management, high-level and construction situation etc. In contrast, 20% of researchers’ most popular topics in construction hazard awareness were hazard identification, recognition, computer vision, virtual reality, tracking, simulation. The results showed that academia focused on high-tech stuff, such as artificial intelligence. However, in sharp contrast, it was seldom mentioned with construction safety and health hazard awareness in Weibo despite artificial intelligence having already become part of our daily lives. © 2022 Elsevier Ltd
Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to compare the focus on construction safety and health hazard awareness between academic literature and laypeople's discussions on Weibo.
Problem: The study addresses the discrepancy in the themes and focal points between academia and the general public concerning construction hazard awareness.
Data: The data consisted of 11,829 Weibo microposts related to construction safety and health hazard awareness and 769 academic articles indexed in Web of Science (WoS) from 1900 to 2021.
Methods_Techniques: The study involved a comparative analysis of the topics discussed in Weibo microposts and academic articles to determine differing priorities and approaches between laypeople and researchers.
Results: The findings revealed that while academic circles concentrated on advanced technological applications like artificial intelligence for hazard identification and risk management, lay discussions rarely touched on these high-tech solutions and instead focused on more immediate and practical concerns like collapse, earthquakes, and safety management.

title: Determining Critical Combinations of Safety Fatality Causes Using Spectral Clustering and Computational Data Mining Algorithms
authors: Assaad, Rayan and El-Adaway, Islam H.
objectives: Although the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) has played a key role in decreasing safety accidents on construction sites, such red
problem: Although the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) has played a key role in decreasin
abstract: Although the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) has played a key role in decreasing safety accidents on construction sites, such reduction is not well perceived among the different types of incidents. For instance, while the injuries resulting in days away from work were substantially decreased, construction fatalities rose in the previous years. While previous safety fatality research work concentrated on studying how different variables could influence the number of fatalities in the construction industry, there is a lack of research efforts that studied the associations, interdependencies, and critical combinations between the different fatality causes. As such, to solve the critical fatality problem that the construction industry is facing, more advanced management methods should be applied. That said, this paper aims to address this important knowledge gap through a methodology based on data-driven computational algorithms. The data analyzed in this paper is comprised of 100 OSHA national fatal accident case files that are prepared by OSHA compliance officers. First, a reference matrix of 100 case files was constructed based on 60 causes that have shown to be the most pertinent to construction fatalities based on a previous study. Second, the spectral clustering computational algorithm was used to cluster the fatality causes based on the strength of their interconnectivities. Third, the frequent pattern data mining and Apriori algorithms were used to determine the critical combinations and associations of causes that mostly contribute to fatal accidents on construction sites. The findings indicate that the 60 fatality causes could be categorized into five clusters. Thus, the most critical combination of fatality causes was determined within each one of the identified clusters. Also, the findings reflected that while safety accidents could happen due to factors or causes that are individually critical, fatalities on construction sites could also result due to a combination of factors that might not be perceived to be critical on the individual level but rather become critical when combined with other factors. This study adds to the body of knowledge by proposing a data-driven accident causation approach to analyze construction fatality accidents, which adds a different dimension to the traditional analysis of safety accidents by factoring possible associations and combinations between different causes. That said, this paper equips safety professionals with a proactive approach that allows them to take the needed preventive actions to avoid fatalities on construction sites by identifying, in hindsight, the critical combinations and associations of fatality causes. Ultimately, the outcomes of this paper would enhance the safety performance in the construction industry and prevent construction fatalities.  © 2021 American Society of Civil Engineers.
Objectives: The study aims to address the knowledge gap in understanding the associations, interdependencies, and critical combinations of fatality causes in construction sites. It proposes a data-driven approach to improve the analysis of construction fatalities and offer proactive prevention strategies.
Problem: While OSHA has contributed to reducing certain types of safety incidents, such as injuries leading to time away from work, construction fatalities have increased. The problem lies in the lack of research on the interdependencies and combinations of fatality causes, which are critical for preventing fatalities.
Data: The data consists of 100 OSHA national fatal accident case files, focusing on 60 causes most pertinent to construction fatalities. These case files were prepared by OSHA compliance officers.
Methods_Techniques: The study employs a reference matrix of the 100 case files based on 60 identified causes. It uses a spectral clustering algorithm to cluster fatality causes based on their interconnectivity, followed by the application of frequent pattern data mining and the Apriori algorithm to determine critical combinations and associations of causes contributing to construction fatalities.
Results: The study identified five clusters of fatality causes, with critical combinations of causes determined within each cluster. It highlighted that while some causes are critical individually, fatalities could also result from combinations of factors that are not critical on their own but become dangerous when combined with others. This approach provides a proactive tool for safety professionals to prevent construction fatalities by identifying critical cause combinations.

title: Improving safety performance in construction using eye-tracking, visual data analytics, and virtual reality
authors: Jeelani, Idris and Albert, Alex and Han, Kevin
objectives: Globally, construction is among the most dangerous industries. Among others, research has demonstrated that construction workers and professionals fai
abstract: Globally, construction is among the most dangerous industries. Among others, research has demonstrated that construction workers and professionals fail to recognize and manage an unacceptable number of safety hazards. To address this, past research has focused on examining several factors including training, education, and management support that may indirectly influence hazard identification and management performance. However, proximal factors associated with poor hazard identification and management at the work interface has received very little attention. This paper summarizes our research aimed at (1) understanding why workers fail to identify and manage safety hazards as they participate in hazard recognition and management efforts and; (2) developing evidence-based interventions to counter poor hazard identification and management performance in the construction industry. This includes examining hazard recognition as a visual search task and understanding how search pattern (i.e., how workers examine the work environment) affects hazard recognition performance. More specifically, the research used eye-tracking technology to examine the relationship between how workers examine the workplace and the resulting hazard identification performance. Based on this new knowledge generated, new interventions were developed to improve hazard recognition and management performance. These include two interventions. First, an immersive hyper-realistic mixed reality training environment that was developed using stereoscopic visual data captured from real construction workplaces. The testing of the intervention with 56 participants suggested that the intervention can significantly improve hazard identification and management performance. Second, an AI-based system that detects hazardous conditions and objects in real-time to assist workers and managers. The system uses the live video captured by a wearable camera to localize the workers on a pre-built global map, detect any hazard present around the worker, and warns them in real-time. The system is tested in indoor and outdoor construction environments, which indicate 93% accuracy in detecting workers' proximity to hazards. © 2020 American Society of Civil Engineers.
Objectives: The study aimed to understand why construction workers fail to effectively identify and manage safety hazards during hazard recognition and management efforts, and to develop evidence-based interventions to improve hazard identification and management performance in the construction industry.
Problem: The construction industry is recognized as one of the most hazardous sectors globally, with a significant problem of workers failing to recognize and manage safety hazards adequately.
Data: The study utilized eye-tracking technology to collect data on workers' examination patterns of their work environments, along with stereoscopic visual data captured from real construction sites for developing mixed reality training environments.
Methods_Techniques: The research involved analyzing hazard recognition as a visual search task using eye-tracking technology, developing an immersive hyper-realistic mixed reality training environment, and creating an AI-based system that uses wearable camera footage to detect hazardous conditions in real-time.
Results: The findings showed that the mixed reality training environment significantly improved hazard identification and management performance among 56 tested participants. The AI-based detection system achieved 93% accuracy in recognizing workers’ proximity to hazards in both indoor and outdoor construction settings.

title: Modelling of the minimum ignition temperature (MIT) of corn dust using statistical analysis and artificial neural networks based on the synergistic effect of concentration and dispersion pressure
authors: Arshad, Ushtar and Taqvi, Syed Ali Ammar and Buang, Azizul
abstract: Corn dust is a highly energetic substance and frequently found in the food manufacturing industries. It not only poses occupational safety hazards such as suffocation or lung disorders for exposed persons but is often extremely explosible in ignition sensitive environment. This probability of explosion can be assessed and minimised with in-depth knowledge of controlling parameters/physical properties that trigger the ignition. This research takes into account the minimum ignition temperature (MIT), which is the control parameter for explosion risk assessment. MIT relies on multiple factors, such as moisture content, particle size, dust concentration, dispersion pressure, humidity and environmental temperature. In this study, the ignition of corn dust clouds was analysed using a Godbert Greenwald furnace for different combinations of dispersion pressure and concentrations. Test findings revealed that the minimum ignition temperature rises with a decrease in particle size. However, the minimum ignition temperature decreases with increased dispersion pressure and concentration until a specific value known as optimal value for ignition. Moreover, this work focuses on a statistical approach of polynomial surface fitting to forecast the MIT based on the combined impact of concentration and dispersion pressure on MIT for corn dust in a real-time experiment. The minimum value of the Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC) was used to select the most appropriate polynomial model due to its authenticity and strong reputation. An artificial neural network (ANN) is also used as a predictive tool to develop a model that can forecast the MIT with a defined combination of dispersion pressures and corn dust concentrations. As soon as an appropriate estimation of this minimum ignition temperature of the combustible dust is confirmed, it is possible to ensure that the temperatures of the surrounding hot surfaces do not rise to that point to prevent the explosion. The predictive results obtained from ANN were found to be good when compared with the polynomial surface fit. Several models with different numbers of neurons have been trained with different transfer functions. For the training, validation, and test phases, R values are around 1.0, i.e., 0.9863, 0.9930, and 0.9893, respectively. The overall R value was 0.9875 for the proposed network. The findings were considered to be acceptable as the overall value of R was close to 1.0. The network obtained sufficiently comparable findings with the research conducted by Kasalova and Balog. © 2021 Institution of Chemical Engineers
Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to assess and minimize the explosion risk of corn dust by determining the minimum ignition temperature (MIT) under various conditions, and to develop predictive models for MIT using polynomial surface fitting and artificial neural networks (ANN).
Problem: Corn dust is a common and highly combustible substance in the food manufacturing industry that poses significant safety hazards, including the risk of explosions in ignition-sensitive environments.
Data: The study used experimental data obtained by analyzing the ignition of corn dust clouds in a Godbert Greenwald furnace, under different dispersion pressures and concentrations of corn dust.
Methods_Techniques: The study employed the following methods: 1. Determining the MIT for corn dust clouds under varying conditions using experimental setups. 2. Polynomial surface fitting to statistically forecast the MIT based on the impacts of concentration and dispersion pressure. 3. Utilization of artificial neural networks (ANN) as predictive tools to model MIT for specific conditions of dispersion pressures and concentrations. 4. Selection of the most appropriate polynomial model was based on the minimum value of the Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC).
Results: Key findings include: 1. The MIT rises with a decrease in particle size and falls with increase in dispersion pressure and concentration until a critical value known as the optimal value for ignition. 2. Predictive results from the ANN were in good agreement with the polynomial surface fit and close to results obtained in previous research by Kasalova and Balog. 3. Several ANN models were trained using different numbers of neurons and transfer functions, showing high R-values (approximate to 1.0) in training, validation, and testing phases, which indicates high accuracy in the predictive capacity of the ANN model.

title: An integrated approach using growing self-organizing map-based genetic K-means clustering and tolerance rough set in occupational risk analysis
authors: Sarkar, Sobhan and Ejaz, Numan and Maiti, J. and Pramanik, Anima
problem: To prevent the occurrences of accidents at workplaces, accident data should be analyzed properly. Ho
abstract: To prevent the occurrences of accidents at workplaces, accident data should be analyzed properly. However, handling such data of higher dimension is often a difficult task for analysis to achieve efficient decision making due to the slow convergence and local minima problem. To address these issues, the present study proposes a new clustering algorithm called growing self-organizing map (GSOM)-based genetic K-means (GSGKM) for classifying accident data into an optimal number of clusters. Tolerance rough set approach (TRSA) is later used on each cluster to extract useful accident patterns, which enables helps in accident analysis and prevention. To validate the effectiveness of our proposed methodology, accident data obtained from an integrated steel plant are used as a case study. Besides, a total of four benchmark datasets collected from the University of California, Irvine (UCI) machine learning repository are also used for comparative study to prove its (i.e., GSGKM) superiority over some other state-of-the-arts. Experimental results reveal that the proposed methodology provides the highest clustering accuracy. A total of four clusters are obtained from the analysis. A set of 16 accident crisp patterns or rules are extracted from clusters using TRSA. Company employees are found to be more exposed to accidents than contractors. Additionally, behavioral issues are identified as the most determinant factor behind the injuries at work. The proposed methodology can be effectively used in decision making for different industries, including construction, manufacturing, and aviation. © 2022, The Author(s), under exclusive licence to Springer-Verlag London Ltd., part of Springer Nature.
Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to propose and test a new clustering algorithm called growing self-organizing map-based genetic K-means (GSGKM) combined with Tolerance Rough Set Approach (TRSA) to enhance accident analysis and prevention in workplaces.
Problem: The study addressed the challenge of analyzing high-dimensional accident data, which is typically complex due to issues like slow convergence and local minima problems that hinder efficient decision-making.
Data: The data used included accident records from an integrated steel plant for a case study, and four benchmark datasets from the University of California, Irvine (UCI) machine learning repository for a comparative study.
Methods_Techniques: The proposed methodology involved the use of the GSGKM algorithm to classify accident data into an optimal number of clusters. Subsequently, the TRSA was applied on each cluster to extract meaningful accident patterns.
Results: The study found that the proposed GSGKM methodology yielded the highest clustering accuracy compared to other state-of-the-art methods. Four clusters were identified with a total of 16 clear accident patterns or rules extracted using TRSA. The analysis also pointed out that company employees are more prone to accidents compared to contractors, and behavioral issues were the most determinant factor for injuries at work. The methodology proved effective for decision-making across various industries.

title: Utilizing safety rule correlation for mobile scaffolds monitoring leveraging deep convolution neural networks
authors: Khan, Numan and Saleem, Muhammad Rakeh and Lee, Doyeop and Park, Man-Woo and Park, Chansik
abstract: Falls from height (FFH) are still a leading cause of fatalities in the construction industry, which also includes scaffolding-related accidents. Despite regular safety inspections, numerous scaffolding-related accidents occur at the construction site. The current safety monitoring practices are not only impractical but infeasible due to dynamicity of construction environment. Since a separate computer training and detection process is generally required to acquire spatiotemporal reasoning to control a single hazard; thus previous efforts in vision intelligence applications to improve safety monitoring are still limited to specific hazards. Also, in regard to detecting unsafe situations based on extracted correlations from safety rules, to date, previous studies have devoted little attention to this domain. To address these issues, this study proposes a correlation-based approach for mobile scaffold safety monitoring and detecting worker's unsafe behaviors. A deep neural network, Mask R-CNN, was used as classification and segmentation of worker's tasks combined with object correlation detection (OCD) module to identify worker's unsafe behaviors. The approach divides the overall construction worker's safety into two subsets, classification of worker and detection of safe (class-1) and unsafe (class-2) behavior using OCD block. The overall performance was evaluated on set of real scenarios with test results showing 85 % and 97 % precision and recall for class-1 (safe behavior) and 91 % and 65 % precision and recall for class-2 (unsafe behavior). The overall accuracy of 86 % confirms the Mask R-CNN-based OCD module's applicability for detecting worker's unsafe behavior effectively in a construction environment. © 2021 Elsevier B.V.
Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to propose a correlation-based approach for mobile scaffold safety monitoring and detecting worker's unsafe behaviors in the construction industry.
Problem: The problem addressed in this study is the high occurrence of deaths from falls from height and scaffolding-related accidents in the construction industry, compounded by the impracticality and infeasibility of current safety monitoring practices due to the dynamic nature of construction sites.
Data: The study utilized a data set consisting of real scenarios from construction sites to test the proposed approach.
Methods_Techniques: The study applied a deep neural network, specifically the Mask R-CNN, enhanced with an object correlation detection (OCD) module. This combination was used for the classification and segmentation of worker tasks, and for identifying unsafe behaviors, dividing worker safety into two categories: safe (class-1) and unsafe (class-2) behavior.
Results: The main findings revealed that the system achieved 85% precision and 97% recall for detecting safe behaviors, and 91% precision and 65% recall for detecting unsafe behaviors, with an overall accuracy of 86%. This confirms the effectiveness of the Mask R-CNN-based OCD module in detecting unsafe behaviors in a construction environment.

title: Scenario-based automated data preprocessing to predict severity of construction accidents
authors: Koc, Kerim and Gurgun, Asli Pelin
abstract: Occupational accidents are common in the construction industry, therefore developing prediction models to detect high severe accidents would be useful. However, existing studies are limited and usually focus on selecting the most appropriate machine learning method rather than identifying the most effective preprocessing pipeline before the prediction. In this study, a scenario-basis automated preprocessing model that identifies the best scenario is developed to predict the severity of construction accidents. The results show that the scenario combination of not removing missing data, not applying data binning, considering outliers, applying Min-Max-Scaler and one-hot encoding, and data resampling with random oversampling yielded the highest prediction performance with 0.6092 of F1-score. Permutation importance of XGBoost analysis indicates that year, cause material, age, past accidents, experience, and salary are the most influential attributes. This study contributes to society/practice through a model preventing high-severe accidents and theory/technology with novel preprocessing model to perform more reliable predictions. © 2022 Elsevier B.V.
Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to develop an automated preprocessing model that can identify the best scenario for predicting the severity of construction accidents.
Problem: The challenge addressed is the lack of focus on preprocessing pipelines in existing studies on predicting accident severity in construction, which have mainly concentrated on selecting machine learning methods.
Data: The abstract does not specify the exact data used; however, it implicitly refers to construction accident data involving attributes like year, cause material, age, past accidents, experience, and salary.
Methods_Techniques: The study implemented a scenario-basis automated preprocessing model that tested various combinations of methods including handling missing data, data binning, outlier consideration, Min-Max-Scaler, one-hot encoding, and data resampling with random oversampling.
Results: The highest performing scenario did not remove missing data, did not apply data binning, considered outliers, applied Min-Max-Scaler and one-hot encoding, and used random oversampling, achieving an F1-score of 0.6092. Permutation importance by XGBoost revealed the most influential attributes to be year, cause material, age, past accidents, experience, and salary.

title: Analysis of Safety Behavior of Prefabricated Building Workers' Hoisting Operation Based on Computer Vision
authors: Xu, Gang
abstract: Safety accidents occur frequently in the construction industry, and unsafe behavior of workers is one of the main reasons for the occurrence of safety accidents. In recent years, the rapid development of emerging technologies has provided effective support for the automatic identification of unsafe behaviors. In particular, computer vision technology does not require equipment to be attached to workers. It has little impact on its operation and can process a large amount of image data in a timely and fast manner. Therefore, it is more suitable for the construction site environment. This study starts from the hoisting operation on the construction site of prefabricated building projects and introduces relevant machine learning methods. Early warning analysis on the safety risk of the tower crane is carried out to complete the hoisting operation of prefabricated components. To suspend dangerous tasks in time according to the warning results, relevant measures are taken and potential risks are eliminated to prevent accidents.  © 2022 Gang Xu.
Objectives: The main goal of the study was to automate the identification of unsafe behaviors in construction sites using machine learning and computer vision technologies in order to facilitate early warnings and intervene promptly in dangerous tasks during hoisting operations in prefabricated building projects.
Problem: The study addresses the frequent occurrence of safety accidents in the construction industry, primarily caused by the unsafe behavior of workers.
Data: The study utilized a large amount of image data collected from construction sites for processing and analysis.
Methods_Techniques: The research applied computer vision technology coupled with machine learning methods to identify unsafe behaviors automatically and provide early warnings concerning the safety risks associated with tower crane operations in construction sites.
Results: The study resulted in the development of a system capable of providing timely warnings and interventions during the hoisting operations of prefabricated components, thus potentially reducing the occurrence of accidents by suspending hazardous tasks based on the warning results.

title: Occupational health knowledge discovery based on association rules applied to workers’ body parts protection: a case study in the automotive industry
authors: Mollaei, Nafiseh and Fujao, Carlos and Rodrigues, Joao and Cepeda, Catia and Gamboa, Hugo
abstract: Occupational Health Protection (OHP) is mandatory by law and can be accomplished by considering the participation of others besides occupational physicians. The data shared can originate knowledge that might influence other processes related to occupational risk prevention. In this study, we used Artificial Intelligence (AI) methods to extract patterns among records shared under these circumstances over two years in the automotive industry. Records featuring OHP data against physical working conditions were selected, and a database of 383 profiles was designed. As Occupational Health Protection profiles under study are associated with work functional ability reduction, the body part(s) (n = 14) where it occurred were identified. Association Rules (ARs) coupled with Natural Language Processing techniques were applied to find meaningful hidden relationships and to identify the occurrence of protection profiles being assigned to at least two body parts simultaneously. After filtering ARs using three metrics (support, confidence, and lift), 54 ARs were found. The distribution of simultaneous body parts is presented as being higher in Special projects (n = 5). The results can use in: (i) design a multi-site body parts functional work ability (loss) model; (ii) model the capacity of organizations to retain workers in their working settings and (iii) prevent work-related musculoskeletal symptoms. © 2022 The Author(s). Published by Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group.
Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to use Artificial Intelligence (AI) methods to identify patterns in Occupational Health Protection (OHP) records to enhance occupational risk prevention and support the design of functional work ability models in the automotive industry.
Problem: The study addressed the challenge of understanding the effectiveness of Occupational Health Protection in reducing functional ability loss due to various working conditions in the automotive industry and how these protections are designated for multiple body parts.
Data: The data comprised a database of 383 OHP profiles from employees in the automotive industry, focusing on records against physical working conditions over two years.
Methods_Techniques: Artificial Intelligence (AI) methods, particularly Association Rules (ARs) and Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques, were used to analyze the data and extract patterns. The ARs were then filtered using three metrics: support, confidence, and lift.
Results: The study discovered 54 significant association rules, indicating patterns in the allocation of protection profiles to at least two body parts simultaneously with a higher distribution observed in special projects. These findings can be used to design multi-site body parts functional work ability loss models, model organizational capacity to retain workers, and prevent work-related musculoskeletal symptoms.

title: Characterizing accident narratives with word embeddings: Improving accuracy, richness, and generalizability
authors: Goldberg, David M.
abstract: Introduction: Ensuring occupational health and safety is an enormous concern for organizations, as accidents not only harm workers but also result in financial losses. Analysis of accident data has the potential to reveal insights that may improve capabilities to mitigate future accidents. However, because accident data are often transcribed textually, analyzing these narratives proves difficult. This study contributes to a recent stream of literature utilizing machine learning to automatically label accident narratives, converting them into more easily analyzable fields. Method: First, a large dataset of accident narratives in which workers were injured is collected from the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA). Word embeddings-based text mining is implemented; compared to past works, this methodology offers excellent performance. Second, to improve the richness of analyses, each record is assessed across five dimensions. The machine learning models provide classifications of body part(s) injured, the source of the injury, the type of event causing the injury, whether a hospitalization occurred, and whether an amputation occurred. Finally, demonstrating generalizability, the trained models are deployed to analyze two additional datasets of accident narratives in the construction industry and the mining and metals industry (transfer learning). Practical Applications: These contributions improve organizations’ capacities to rapidly analyze textual accident narratives. © 2021 The Author
Objectives: The main purpose of the study is to utilize machine learning for automatically labeling accident narratives to facilitate easier analysis and improve occupational health and safety strategies.
Problem: The challenge addressed is the difficulty in analyzing accident data due to its textual format, which complicates extracting actionable insights.
Data: The data used in the study includes a large dataset of textual accident narratives collected from the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), focusing on narratives where workers were injured. Additional datasets from the construction and mining and metals industries were also analyzed.
Methods_Techniques: The study applied word embeddings-based text mining, which showed excellent performance compared to previous methods. Machine learning models were used to classify each record across five dimensions: body part(s) injured, the source of the injury, the type of event causing the injury, hospitalization occurrences, and amputation occurrences. The models were then tested for generalizability through transfer learning on other industry datasets.
Results: The primary result was the effective classification of accident narratives across specified dimensions, improving the organization's capability to quickly and accurately analyze textual data. This facilitates better understanding and prevention of workplace accidents.

title: Random Forest Analysis of Occupational Accident Reports among Roofing Contractors
authors: Onuchukwu, Ikechukwu S. and Esmaeili, Behzad
abstract: One of the trades most susceptible to occupational hazards in the construction industry is roofing contractors, whose projects inherently involve exposure to falls from height. In response, this study used a random forest data mining technique to analyze the impacts of accidents' contributing factors on roofers' injuries. The analysis examined over 600 incidents obtained from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA's) database of fatal and nonfatal accident reports. Some of the contributing factors considered include source of injury, cause of injury, project cost, project end use, project type, injured body part, and day of injury. The results of validated random forest model revealed that the most important factor for predicting the nature of injury is injured body part followed by source of injury. The presented results can be used by managers, policymakers, and safety professionals to reduce the frequency and severity of incidents. © 2022 ASCE.
Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to analyze the impact of various contributing factors on injuries sustained by roofing contractors in the construction industry, using data mining techniques.
Problem: Roofing contractors in the construction industry are highly vulnerable to occupational hazards, particularly falls from height, which poses a significant risk of injuries.
Data: The study analyzed over 600 incidents reported in the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) database, which included both fatal and nonfatal accident reports.
Methods_Techniques: The study employed the random forest data mining technique to identify and analyze the factors contributing to roofers' injuries.
Results: The analysis revealed that the most critical factor for predicting the nature of injury was the injured body part, followed by the source of injury. These findings can aid managers, policymakers, and safety professionals in mitigating the frequency and severity of roofing accidents.

title: Probabilistic Machine Learning with Low-Cost Sensor Networks for Occupational Exposure Assessment and Industrial Hygiene Decision Making
authors: Patton, Andrew N and Medvedovsky, Konstantin and Zuidema, Christopher and Peters, Thomas M and Koehler, Kirsten
abstract: Occupational exposure assessments are dominated by small sample sizes and low spatial and temporal resolution with a focus on conducting Occupational Safety and Health Administration regulatory compliance sampling. However, this style of exposure assessment is likely to underestimate true exposures and their variability in sampled areas, and entirely fail to characterize exposures in unsampled areas. The American Industrial Hygiene Association (AIHA) has developed a more realistic system of exposure ratings based on estimating the 95th percentiles of the exposures that can be used to better represent exposure uncertainty and exposure variability for decision-making; however, the ratings can still fail to capture realistic exposure with small sample sizes. Therefore, low-cost sensor networks consisting of numerous lower-quality sensors have been used to measure occupational exposures at a high spatiotemporal scale. However, the sensors must be calibrated in the laboratory or field to a reference standard. Using data from carbon monoxide (CO) sensors deployed in a heavy equipment manufacturing facility for eight months from August 2017 to March 2018, we demonstrate that machine learning with probabilistic gradient boosted decision trees (GBDT) can model raw sensor readings to reference data highly accurately, entirely removing the need for laboratory calibration. Further, we indicate how the machine learning models can produce probabilistic hazard maps of the manufacturing floor, creating a visual tool for assessing facility-wide exposures. Additionally, the ability to have a fully modeled prediction distribution for each measurement enables the use of the AIHA exposure ratings, which provide an enhanced industrial decision-making framework as opposed to simply determining if a small number of measurements were above or below a pertinent occupational exposure limit. Lastly, we show how a probabilistic modeling exposure assessment with high spatiotemporal resolution data can prevent exposure misclassifications associated with traditional models that rely exclusively on mean or point predictions. © 2021 The Author(s) 2021. Published by Oxford University Press on behalf of the British Occupational Hygiene Society.
Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to demonstrate the application of machine learning techniques using probabilistic gradient boosted decision trees to model raw sensor readings for occupational exposure assessments, completely eliminating the need for laboratory calibration. The study aimed to use these models to generate probabilistic hazard maps and improve decision-making in industrial settings using the American Industrial Hygiene Association (AIHA) exposure ratings.
Problem: The problem addressed in this study is the traditional approach in occupational exposure assessments that often relies on small sample sizes and low spatial and temporal resolution. These methods likely underestimate true exposures and their variability while failing to characterize exposures at all in unsampled areas.
Data: The data used in this study came from carbon monoxide sensors, which were deployed in a heavy equipment manufacturing facility over a period of eight months, from August 2017 to March 2018.
Methods_Techniques: The study employed machine learning with probabilistic gradient boosted decision trees (GBDT) to accurately model raw sensor readings against reference data. This method allowed the researchers to bypass the need for traditional laboratory calibration and to produce fully modeled prediction distributions for each measurement.
Results: The main findings of the study include the successful elimination of the need for laboratory calibration of sensors through the application of machine learning models. These models could generate probabilistic hazard maps, which provide a visual tool for assessing facility-wide exposures. Furthermore, the results indicated the potential of machine learning to use AIHA exposure ratings effectively in decision-making processes and to prevent misclassification of exposures that might occur with traditional models based on mean or point predictions.

title: REFRAMING PSMS IN THE CONTEXT OF OPERATIONAL RISK MANAGEMENT AND ESG SUSTAINABILITY
authors: Marshall, Michael and Fingerhut, Martin
objectives: Current Environmental, Health, and Safety (EHS) and Asset Integrity/Performance Management (AIM/APM) platforms fail to properly aggregate data from mu
problem: Current Environmental, Health, and Safety (EHS) and Asset Integrity/Performance Management (AIM/APM)
abstract: Current Environmental, Health, and Safety (EHS) and Asset Integrity/Performance Management (AIM/APM) platforms fail to properly aggregate data from multiple Pipeline Safety Management System (PSMS) workflows into a single database which can be queried to inform real-time, risk-based analyses and decision-making relative to profitability impacts. With predictive analytics at the core of an asset integrity and PSMS framework intent upon achieving holistic, enterprise-wide visibility and accountability for Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) program effectiveness and sustainability, this paper proposes an ideal solution designed around the following core functions: • Reframing EHS and AIM/APM in the context of Operational Risk Management (ORM) by normalizing data relative to performance and process-related parameters • Categorizing, prioritizing, and risk ranking incidents by economic impact (specifically lost production), enabling problem solving teams to resolve high value deep-dive systemic problems • Satisfying the need for a one-stop system that has the highly interlinked EHS, compliance and enterprise risk management systems all in one framework • Linking to data historians like OSIsoft PI to “give voice to equipment” for predictive analytics as necessitated by today's digital transformation movement • Featuring incident investigation, reporting and failure modes decision support functionality based on industry best practice standards including API 754 Process Safety Performance Indicators for Refining and Petrochemical Industries, which is also directly applicable to petroleum pipeline industry operating systems and processes where loss of containment may occur • Offering a highly configurable user interface for key performance indicator (KPI) trending, reporting, alerts/notifications, action planning and follow-up. Copyright © 2022 by ASME.
Objectives: The main purpose of this study is to propose an effective solution that integrates Environmental, Health, and Safety (EHS) and Asset Integrity/Performance Management (AIM/APM) with Pipeline Safety Management System (PSMS) data into a comprehensive Operational Risk Management (ORM) framework that enhances real-time, risk-based decision-making and profitability analysis.
Problem: The study addresses the current inefficiencies in EHS and AIM/APM platforms, specifically their failure to aggregate data from various PSMS workflows into a unified database that supports real-time, risk-based analyses and impacts on profitability.
Data: The data integration proposed in the study involves reframing EHS and AIM/APM in the context of ORM by normalizing performance and process-related parameters, along with linking to data historians like OSIsoft PI.
Methods_Techniques: The methods proposed include categorizing, prioritizing, and risk-ranking incidents by economic impact, incorporating predictive analytics to enhance data visibility and voice of equipment, and applying best practice standards such as API 754 for Process Safety Performance Indicators. The solution also involves setting up a one-stop system that merges highly interlinked systems of EHS, compliance, and enterprise risk management in one framework.
Results: The proposed solution facilitates holistic, enterprise-wide visibility and accountability, ensuring effective Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) program effectiveness and sustainability. This is achieved through a highly configurable user interface that allows for trending of key performance indicators (KPIs), incident investigation, reporting, and decision support for failure modes.

title: Beware the Grizzlyman: A comparison of job- and industry-based noise exposure estimates using manual coding and the NIOSH NIOCCS machine learning algorithm
authors: Roberts, Benjamin and Shkembi, Abas and Smith, Lauren M. and Neitzel, Richard L.
abstract: Recently, the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) released an updated version of the NIOSH Industry and Occupation Computerized Coding System (NIOCCS), which uses supervised machine learning to assign industry and occupational codes based on provided free-text information. However, no efforts have been made to externally verify the quality of assigned industry and job titles when the algorithm is provided with inputs of varying quality. This study sought to evaluate whether the NIOCCS algorithm was sufficiently robust with low-quality inputs and how variable quality could impact subsequent job estimated exposures in a large job-exposure matrix for noise (NoiseJEM). Using free-text industry and job descriptions from >700,000 noise measurements in the NoiseJEM, three files were created and input into NIOCCS: (1) N1, “raw” industries and job titles; (2) N2, “refined” industries and “raw” job titles; and (3) N3, “refined” industries and job titles. Standardized industry and occupation codes were output by NIOCCS. Descriptive statistics of performance metrics (e.g., misclassification/discordance of occupation codes) were evaluated for each input relative to the original NoiseJEM dataset (N0). Across major Standardized Occupational Classifications (SOC), total discordance rates for N1, N2, and N3 compared to N0 were 53.6%, 42.3%, and 5.0%, respectively. The impact of discordance on the major SOC group varied and included both over- and under-estimates of average noise exposure compared to N0. N2 had the most accurate noise exposure estimates (i.e., smallest bias) across major SOC groups compared to N1 and N3. Further refinement of job titles in N3 showed little improvement. Some variation in classification efficacy was seen over time, particularly prior to 1985. Machine learning algorithms can systematically and consistently classify data but are highly dependent on the quality and amount of input data. The greatest benefit for an end-user may come from cleaning industry information before applying this method for job classification. Our results highlight the need for standardized classification methods that remain constant over time. © 2022 JOEH, LLC.
Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to evaluate the robustness of the NIOCCS algorithm when provided with low-quality inputs and assess how variations in input quality impact the accuracy of job exposure estimates in a large job-exposure matrix for noise.
Problem: The challenge addressed was the lack of external validation of the NIOCCS algorithm's performance in assigning accurate industry and occupational codes when faced with varying qualities of free-text inputs.
Data: The data used included over 700,000 noise measurements from the NoiseJEM, alongside differentially prepared free-text descriptions of industries and job titles to evaluate the NIOCCS algorithm's performance.
Methods_Techniques: The study involved creating three distinct files with varying levels of refined inputs: (1) “raw” industries and job titles (N1), (2) “refined” industries and “raw” job titles (N2), and (3) “refined” industries and job titles (N3), and then processing these through NIOCCS. The output codes were compared using descriptive statistics to assess misclassification and discordance rates against the original, unaltered dataset (N0).
Results: The findings revealed discordance rates of 53.6% for N1, 42.3% for N2, and 5.0% for N3 when compared to N0, showcasing that input refinement markedly improves coding accuracy. N2 provided the most accurate noise exposure estimates across major SOC groups with minimal bias, but further refinement in N3 showed little improvement in performance. The study also noted variation in classification efficacy over time, especially before 1985, emphasizing the influence of input quality on machine learning algorithm outcomes.

title: Using Big Data to Improve Safety Performance: An Application of Process Mining to Enhance Data Visualisation
authors: Pika, Anastasiia and ter Hofstede, Arthur H.M. and Perrons, Robert K. and Grossmann, Georg and Stumptner, Markus and Cooley, Jim
abstract: The management of health and safety plays an important role in safety performance, and is therefore an important foundational element in an organisation's overall sustainable development. Many organisations are now able to collect vast amounts of data to shed light on the underlying causes behind accidents and safety-related incidents, and to spot patterns that can lead to solutions. Despite these well-intentioned Big Data collection efforts, however, accident statistics in asset-intensive industries remain stubbornly high as the data frequently fails to reveal actionable insights. In this paper, we answer Wang and Wu's (2020) [60] and Wang et al.'s (2019) [61] calls for the application of Big Data science to the safety domain by exploring the potential of applying tools and techniques from process mining, a research area concerned with analysing process execution data, to derive novel insights from and improve the visualisation of safety process data. We demonstrate how these tools can yield useful insights in the occupational health and safety domain by analysing process execution data from a Permit to Work system in an Australian energy company. Specifically, the analysis presented here highlights the underlying complexity of the organisation's Permit to Work process, reveals conformance and performance issues, and uncovers resources associated with conformance issues and changes in the frequency of such issues over time, thereby underlining the need to simplify the system. Encouraged by these fresh perspectives and insights delivered by process mining, we hope that this novel application will be a catalyst for further research at the interface between these research disciplines. © 2021 Elsevier Inc.
Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to apply Big Data science, specifically tools and techniques from process mining, to the safety domain in order to derive novel insights and improve visualization of safety process data.
Problem: Despite the collection of vast amounts of data in asset-intensive industries, the high accident statistics remain unchanged because the data often does not provide actionable insights.
Data: The study used process execution data from a Permit to Work system within an Australian energy company.
Methods_Techniques: Process mining methods were applied to analyze the process execution data, aiming to understand the complexity of the Permit to Work process, examine conformance and performance issues, and identify resources associated with these issues.
Results: The analysis revealed the complexity of the Permit to Work process, identified specific conformance and performance issues, and disclosed changes in the frequency of these issues over time. These insights suggest a need to simplify the system, offering a new perspective that could serve as a catalyst for further research at the interface between Big Data science and safety management.

title: Artificial Intelligence (AI) Coupled with the Internet of Things (IoT) for the Enhancement of Occupational Health and Safety in the Construction Industry
authors: Palaniappan, Kavitha and Kok, Chiang Liang and Kato, Kenichi
problem: The Singapore WSH (Workplace Safety and Health) Council states that 6 out of 17 fatal injuries in th
abstract: The Singapore WSH (Workplace Safety and Health) Council states that 6 out of 17 fatal injuries in the first half of the year 2019 are from the Construction industry and that the top 3 causes of the fatal and major injuries are mainly falling from heights, machinery-related injuries and slips, trips or falls. The government does come up with various frameworks to reduce such accidents and incidents, incorporating the 4 main factors: policy, personnel, process and incentive factors. However, it has been found that still almost 25% of the safety hazards go unnoticed by the workers. One must understand that hazard identification at site is a visual search and analysis process which can be hindered by various human factors such as the workers’ physiological and psychological state of mind, attention span, bias and risk tolerance levels. This paper explores the possibilities of coupling AI with IoT to overcome those challenges. © 2021, The Author(s), under exclusive license to Springer Nature Switzerland AG.
Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to explore how coupling Artificial Intelligence (AI) with the Internet of Things (IoT) can enhance hazard identification in the construction industry to overcome the limitations posed by human factors.
Problem: Despite various government frameworks aimed at reducing workplace accidents, about 25% of safety hazards still go unnoticed by construction workers, largely due to human factors such as physiological and psychological states, attention span, bias, and risk tolerance levels.
Data: The paper does not specify the exact data used but discusses workplace safety statistics from the Singapore WSH (Workplace Safety and Health) Council regarding fatal injuries in the construction industry during the first half of 2019.
Methods_Techniques: The study suggests the integration of AI with IoT as a method to improve hazard identification at construction sites, though specific techniques and processes of implementation are not detailed in the abstract.
Results: The abstract does not provide specific outcomes or results from the implementation of AI and IoT technologies in hazard identification, focusing instead on the potential of such technologies to address the problem.

title: MetaInjury: Meta-learning framework for reusing the risk knowledge of different construction accidents
authors: Li, Xin and Zhu, Rongchen and Ye, Han and Jiang, Chunxiao and Benslimane, Abderrahim
abstract: In recent years, many scholars have used data mining algorithms to discover the laws related to the prevention of occupational injuries in the construction industry. Using accident injury records to model occupational risk is a promising direction (for example, predict injury risk from accident frequency and severity). However, the records of specific accident injury data are relatively limited, bringing great difficulties for people to obtain risk knowledge and establish an effective accident consequence prediction model. This article proposes a meta-learning framework called MetaInjury, which can help safety managers share risk knowledge and predict the risk of work-related injuries in various construction industry accidents. When facing small sample data of a new accident type, we first calculate the document vector of the accident description and compare its center vector with vectors in the Meta-knowledge database to find the type of accident most similar. Then, we correspond the meta-features with the best machine learning algorithms on the data set to implement the recommendation of accident prediction algorithms. Through finding the most similar cases and the recommended algorithm, important accident risk factors and accident assessment rules can be shared by safety managers to realize effective risk management. Moreover, specific small sample accident consequences can be predicted by the recommended algorithm. Finally, we verify the method's effectiveness in four different small sample accident data. The results show that the MetaInjury framework can provide theoretical support for preventing small sample accidents and injury reduction in the construction industry. © 2021
Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to develop a meta-learning framework called MetaInjury to enhance the ability to share risk knowledge and predict the risk of work-related injuries in various construction industry accidents, especially when dealing with small sample data of new accident types.
Problem: The challenge addressed was the limited availability of specific accident injury data, which complicates obtaining risk knowledge and establishing effective accident consequence prediction models in the construction industry.
Data: The study utilized accident injury records and engaged in modeling based on these records to predict occupational risks in the construction industry.
Methods_Techniques: The MetaInjury framework uses a process to first calculate the document vector of an accident description and determine its proximity to vectors in a Meta-knowledge database to identify similar accident types. It then correlates meta-features with appropriate machine learning algorithms to recommend accident prediction algorithms.
Results: The results demonstrated that the MetaInjury framework effectively supports the prevention of small sample accidents and injury reduction in the construction industry by enabling safety managers to share important accident risk factors and assessment rules, and predict specific small sample accident consequences using the recommended algorithms.

title: Health risks of occupational exposure to toxic chemicals in coal mine workplaces based on risk assessment mathematical model based on deep learning
authors: Fan, Zhao and Xu, Fanyu
abstract: With the increasing demand for energy in China, more and more coal mines are mined. At the same time, along with the safety and health risks brought by occupational exposure in mine operation, it is very important to assess the risk of toxic substances in the working environment. The purpose of this study is to evaluate and analyze the health risk of occupational exposure to toxic chemicals in coal mines based on deep learning algorithm and mathematical model. In this study, the working environment and employees of four working areas in a mine in Shanxi Province were selected as the research objects, and the gas in the working environment was sampled. Through the methods of mathematical evaluation model and single factor evaluation grade, the lung condition of employees and the content of harmful gas components were calculated, and the risk index of the area was obtained. The experimental results show that in the range of 0.56 kg/s–3.06 kg/s, the induced airflow velocity of chute increases by 54%, and the induced airflow velocity of guide chute increases by 53%. It shows that the increase of induced airflow velocity increases significantly with the increase of coal cutting amount, and the content of harmful substances in the working environment is higher. It is concluded that the deep learning mathematical model in this study is very effective and accurate in the health risk assessment caused by toxic chemicals in coal mines, and contributes to the risk assessment. It is very important for the safety management of the workers in the mine. © 2021 Elsevier B.V.
Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to evaluate and analyze the health risk of occupational exposure to toxic chemicals in coal mines, using a deep learning algorithm and mathematical model.
Problem: The study addressed the challenge of assessing the risk from toxic substances in the working environment of coal mines, owing to the rise in mining activities in China and associated safety and health risks.
Data: The study used data collected from the working environment and employees of four different areas within a coal mine in Shanxi Province. This included samples of gases present in the working areas.
Methods_Techniques: The researchers employed deep learning algorithms coupled with mathematical evaluation models and a single factor evaluation grade technique to compute the lung condition of mine workers and the concentration of harmful gases, and ultimately derive a risk index for the area.
Results: The findings indicate that when the coal cutting amount increases, the induced airflow velocity in chutes and guide chutes also increases significantly (54% and 53%, respectively). This increase correlates with higher concentrations of harmful substances in the environment. The study validates the effectiveness and accuracy of the deep learning mathematical model in assessing health risks linked to toxic chemicals in coal mines, emphasizing its importance for the safety management of mine workers.

title: Intelligent robot for worker safety surveillance: Deep learning perception and visual navigation
authors: Lee, Min-Fan Ricky and Chien, Tzu-Wei
abstract: The fatal injury rate for the construction industry is higher than the average for all industries. Recently, researchers have shown an increased interest in occupational safety in the construction industry. However, all the current methods using conventional machine learning with stationary cameras suffer from some severe limitations, perceptual aliasing (e.g., different places/objects can appear identical), occlusion (e.g., place/object appearance changes between visits), seasonal / illumination changes, significant viewpoint changes, etc. This paper proposes a perception module using end-to-end deep-learning and visual SLAM (Simultaneous Localization and Mapping) for an effective and efficient object recognition and navigation using a differential-drive mobile robot. Various deep-learning frameworks and visual navigation strategies with evaluation metrics are implemented and validated for the selection of the best model. The deep-learning model's predictions are evaluated via the metrics (model speed, accuracy, complexity, precision, recall, P-R curve, F1 score). The YOLOv3 shows the best trade-off among all algorithms, 57.9% mean average precision (mAP), in real-world settings, and can process 45 frames per second (FPS) on NVIDIA Jetson TX2 which makes it suitable for real-time detection, as well as a right candidate for deploying the neural network on a mobile robot. The evaluation metrics used for the comparison of laser SLAM are Root Mean Square Error (RMSE). The Google Cartographer SLAM shows the lowest RMSE and acceptable processing time. The experimental results demonstrate that the perception module can meet the requirements of head protection criteria in Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) standards for construction. To be more precise, this module can effectively detect construction worker's non-hardhat-use in different construction site conditions and can facilitate improved safety inspection and supervision.  © 2020 IEEE.
Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to propose a perception module using end-to-end deep learning and visual SLAM for effective and efficient object recognition and navigation applied specifically to improve occupational safety in the construction industry.
Problem: Existing methods in occupational safety that utilize conventional machine learning with stationary cameras face challenges such as perceptual aliasing, occlusion, changes due to seasonal variations and illumination, and significant viewpoint changes, which reduce their effectiveness and reliability in the construction industry.
Data: The data used included real-world settings in the construction industry to test the proposed deep learning models and visual SLAM strategies.
Methods_Techniques: The study implemented various deep learning frameworks and visual navigation strategies, along with evaluation metrics like model speed, accuracy, complexity, precision, recall, P-R curve, and F1 score, to select the best model for deployment on a mobile robot. The YOLOv3 algorithm was specifically evaluated, and the Google Cartographer SLAM was used for laser SLAM assessments.
Results: The YOLOv3 demonstrated a favorable balance between performance metrics with a mean average precision of 57.9% and an ability to process 45 frames per second on NVIDIA Jetson TX2, making it suitable for real-time detection and deployment on mobile robots. The Google Cartographer SLAM showed the lowest RMSE, indicating reliable performance in terms of localization and mapping, and acceptable processing times. The perception module was proven to effectively detect construction workers not using hard hats under various site conditions and could enhance safety inspection and supervision in line with OSHA standards.

title: Individual Environmental Risk Assessment and Management in Industry 4.0: An IoT-Based Model
authors: Lemos, Janaína and Gaspar, Pedro D. and Lima, Tânia M.
abstract: This paper addresses the design of a system to facilitate individual environmental risk assessment and long-term risk management in the Industry 4.0 work context. The solution is based on IoT to provide data related to workers’ exposure to hazardous agents (dust, noise, ultraviolet radiation, poor lighting, and inappropriate temperature and humidity) through a simple interface for employees and employers. The system includes a monitoring device and a server and performs employee registration, receives secure messages from the monitoring devices, shows information about the workers’ exposure, and triggers alarms when the measures reach or exceed the limits established by applicable legislation and/or standards. The system was tested in a controlled environment, and the results are presented in this work. Our solution is still under development, and in future stages, it will include a smartphone app for employees to check their exposures and the use of artificial intelligence on the server, which is expected to enable long-term planning by companies based on the analysis of employees’ health history and their exposures to hazardous agents. © 2022 by the authors.
Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to design a system that aids in individual environmental risk assessment and long-term risk management within the context of Industry 4.0.
Problem: The challenge addressed was the need for a reliable system to monitor and manage workers' exposure to hazardous agents in the workplace, such as dust, noise, ultraviolet radiation, poor lighting, and inappropriate temperature and humidity.
Data: Data for this study was collected using IoT devices that monitored various hazardous agents in the workplace.
Methods_Techniques: The study implemented a system comprising a monitoring device and a server. It involved employee registration, securing messages from monitoring devices, displaying exposure information, and triggering alarms based on legislative and standard limits. The system was tested in a controlled environment.
Results: The results from the controlled environment tests are discussed in the paper. The system, though still under development, successfully monitored and reported on hazardous exposures, and future enhancements will include a smartphone app for employee use and artificial intelligence for data analysis and long-term planning.

title: Machine Learning-Based Risk Analysis for Construction Worker Safety from Ubiquitous Site Photos and Videos
authors: Tang, Shuai and Golparvar-Fard, Mani
abstract: This paper proposes a new method for single-worker severity level prediction from already collected site images and video clips. Onsite safety observers often assess workers' severity levels during construction activities. While risk analysis is key to improving long-term construction site safety, omnipresent monitoring is still time-consuming and costly to implement. The recent growth of visual data captured actively on construction sites has opened a new opportunity to increase the frequency of worker safety monitoring. This paper shows that a comprehensive vision-based assessment is the most informative to automatically infer worker severity level from images. Efficient computer vision models are presented to conduct this risk analysis. The method is validated on a challenging image dataset first of its kind. Specifically, the proposed method detects and evaluates the worker state from visual data, defined by (1) worker body posture, (2) the usage of personal protective equipment, (3) worker interactions with tools and materials, (4) the construction activity being performed, and (5) the presence of surrounding workplace hazards. To estimate the worker state, a multitasked recognition model is introduced that recognizes objects, activity, and keypoints from visual data simultaneously, taking 36.6% less time and 40.1% less memory while keeping comparably performances compared to a system running individual models for each subtask. Worker activity recognition is further improved with a spatio-temporal graph neural network model using recognized per-frame worker activity, detected bounding boxes of tools and materials, and estimated worker poses. Finally, severity levels are predicted by a trained classifier on a dataset of images of construction workers accompanied with ground truth severity level annotations. In the test dataset assembled from real-world projects, the severity level prediction model achieves 85.7% cross-validation accuracy in a bricklaying task and 86.6% cross-validation accuracy for a plastering task, demonstrating the potential for near real-time worker safety detection and severity assessment. © 2021 American Society of Civil Engineers.
Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to propose and validate a new method for predicting single-worker severity levels using site images and video clips to enhance frequency and accuracy of safety monitoring on construction sites.
Problem: The challenge addressed was the time-consuming and costly nature of omnipresent safety monitoring on construction sites, despite the critical importance of risk analysis for long-term safety enhancements.
Data: The study utilized a challenging image dataset, which included images of construction workers annotated with ground truth severity level annotations.
Methods_Techniques: The researchers developed efficient computer vision models for risk analysis, implementing a multitask recognition model that processes objects, activity, and keypoints from visual data simultaneously. This included a spatio-temporal graph neural network for improving worker activity recognition through the use of per-frame activity, tool and material bounding boxes, and worker poses. Finally, a trained classifier was used for predicting severity levels.
Results: The prediction model demonstrated 85.7% cross-validation accuracy for bricklaying tasks and 86.6% cross-validation accuracy for plastering tasks, showcasing significant potential for real-time worker safety detection and severity assessment in construction environments.

title: Quantitative health risk assessment of respiratory exposure to 1,3-Butadiene in a petrochemical industry
authors: Yarandi, Mohsen Sadeghi and Karimi, Ali and Sajedian, Ali Asghar and Ahmadi, Vahid and Golbabaei, Farideh
objectives: Background and aims: In recent decades, air quality in different work environments has been a major concern. It is clear that the chemical materials u
abstract: Background and aims: In recent decades, air quality in different work environments has been a major concern. It is clear that the chemical materials used in industries have a profound effect on the quality of workplace air. In 1942, the number of identified chemicals was about 600,000, in 1947 it was about 4 million, and in 2011 it was about 18 million, while the number of new chemical compounds increased from 1,000 to 2,000 annually. Many people around the world are exposed to a variety of chemicals in various working environment. Exposure to these substances can lead to numerous health and carcinogenic effects on individuals. Among these substances, volatile organic compounds are one of the main contributors to air pollution and due to high vapor pressure, high evaporation rate and rapid release into the environment, many people are exposed and consequently have irreversible effects on their health in various occupations. Petrochemical industry is one of the industries where workers are exposed to high levels of chemical pollutants in their respiratory air. One of the hazardous volatile organic compounds used in workplaces, including petrochemicals, is 1,3-butadiene (molecular formula: C4H6). 1,3-Butadiene is a colorless gas with smells like gasoline. Many international agencies and government organizations, including the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), have identified this chemical as a human carcinogen by inhalation and placed it in Group 1 of carcinogens. Health effects of this compound include stimulation of the nervous system, eyes, nose, airways, asthma, fatigue, low blood pressure, and heart rate as well as atrophy in the ovaries. Today, many international organizations, including the World Health Organization (WHO) and the US Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA), consider the use of quantitative risk assessment methods as the legal basis for chemical compounds. Generally, the health risk assessment process involves several steps. First, it identify the existing hazards, then measuring the individual's exposure, finally determining the relevant factors and measuring and evaluating the individual's exposure to a particular substance. Afterwards, using different risk assessment methods, graphs and dose-response values, the probability of adverse effects in the population is calculated. Therefore, due to the deleterious effects of the 1,3- butadiene on the health of those working in the petrochemical industry, and the lack of similar studies in Iran to assess the health risk of the respiratory exposure to 1,3-butadiene in the petrochemical industry, the present study aimed to assess the health risk of occupational exposure to 1,3-butadiene vapors in a petrochemical industry in Iran. Methods: This cross-sectional study was conducted in the petrochemical industry that produce copolymer ABS (acrylonitrile, butadiene, styrene) in Iran in 2018.
