abstract: Occupational safety hazards and risk management in construction industries are major worldwide concerns due to the unique dynamic nature of their working environment. Safety-related documentations such as injury reports, physical demand analyses (PDAs), and standard operating procedures (SOPs) contain valuable information to support the risk prevention algo-rithms. This paper presents a blended study on occupational risk assessment, in perspective with both attribute-based and data mining approaches. The study explored a strategy of attribute-based identification and degree of risk classification by applying distinctive quantitative analysis on the level of injuries. Data mining analysis further exposed the causality links of potentially hazardous activities and injuries. A conceptual digital transformation framework is proposed to assess digital mapping and future predictive measurements for up-to-date risk factor evaluation. The blended analysis is expected to help the construction industry identify relationships on causes of safety hazards, key safety attributes, as well as their corresponding risk controls. © 2022 The Author(s). Permission for reuse (free in most cases) can be obtained from copyright.com.
Objectives: The main purpose of this study is to enhance occupational risk assessment in the construction industry using both attribute-based and data mining approaches to improve the understanding and mitigation of safety hazards.
Problem: The challenge addressed is the dynamic and dangerous nature of construction work environments, necessitating improved methods for assessing and managing safety risks through the analysis of safety-related documentation.
Data: The study utilized safety-related documentations including injury reports, physical demand analyses (PDAs), and standard operating procedures (SOPs).
Methods_Techniques: The research applied an attribute-based approach for identification and risk classification based on the level of injuries, coupled with data mining techniques to unveil causality links between hazardous activities and injuries. A conceptual digital transformation framework was also proposed for digital mapping and future risk predictions.
Results: The study identified relationships between causes of safety hazards and key safety attributes, alongside corresponding risk controls. The blend of attribute-based recognition and data mining facilitated a thorough understanding and management of risk factors in the construction industry.

title: Deep Learning Models for Health and Safety Risk Prediction in Power Infrastructure Projects
authors: Ajayi, Anuoluwapo and Oyedele, Lukumon and Owolabi, Hakeem and Akinade, Olugbenga and Bilal, Muhammad and Davila Delgado, Juan Manuel and Akanbi, Lukman
problem: Inappropriate management of health and safety (H&S) risk in power infrastructure projects can result
abstract: Inappropriate management of health and safety (H&S) risk in power infrastructure projects can result in occupational accidents and equipment damage. Accidents at work have detrimental effects on workers, company, and the general public. Despite the availability of H&S incident data, utilizing them to mitigate accident occurrence effectively is challenging due to inherent limitations of existing data logging methods. In this study, we used a text-mining approach for retrieving meaningful terms from data and develop six deep learning (DL) models for H&S risks management in power infrastructure. The DL models include DNNclassify (risk or no risk), DNNreg1 (loss time), DNNreg2 (body injury), DNNreg3 (plant and fleet), DNNreg4 (equipment), and DNNreg5 (environment). An H&S risk database obtained from a leading UK power infrastructure construction company was used in developing the models using the H2O framework of the R language. Performances of DL models were assessed and benchmarked with existing models using test data and appropriate performance metrics. The overall accuracy of the classification model was 0.93. The average R2 value for the five regression models was 0.92, with mean absolute error between 0.91 and 0.94. The presented results, in addition to the developed user-interface module, will help practitioners obtain a better understanding of H&S challenges, minimize project costs (such as third-party insurance and equipment repairs), and offer effective strategies to mitigate H&S risk. © 2019 Society for Risk Analysis
Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to enhance health and safety (H&S) risk management in power infrastructure projects by developing deep learning models.
Problem: The study addressed the challenge of effectively utilizing health and safety incident data to mitigate accident occurrences in power infrastructure, due to limitations in existing data logging methods.
Data: The study utilized an H&S risk database sourced from a leading UK power infrastructure construction company.
Methods_Techniques: A text-mining approach was employed to extract meaningful terms from the data and develop six deep learning models using the H2O framework of the R language. The models developed include DNNclassify (to classify risk or no risk), DNNreg1 (loss time), DNNreg2 (body injury), DNNreg3 (plant and fleet), DNNreg4 (equipment), and DNNreg5 (environment).
Results: The deep learning models demonstrated high performance, with the classification model achieving an overall accuracy of 0.93 and the regression models averaging an R^2 value of 0.92. These models, alongside a developed user-interface module, are expected to help practitioners better understand and manage H&S challenges, reduce project costs, and implement effective risk mitigation strategies.

title: Optimised Big Data analytics for health and safety hazards prediction in power infrastructure operations
authors: Ajayi, Anuoluwapo and Oyedele, Lukumon and Akinade, Olugbenga and Bilal, Muhammad and Owolabi, Hakeem and Akanbi, Lukman and Delgado, Juan Manuel Davila
abstract: Forecasting imminent accidents in power infrastructure projects require a robust and accurate prediction model to trigger a proactive strategy for risk mitigation. Unfortunately, getting ready-made machine learning algorithms to eliminate redundant features optimally is challenging, especially if the parameters of these algorithms are not tuned. In this study, a particle swarm optimization is proposed both for feature selection and parameters tuning of the gradient boosting machine technique on 1,349,239 data points of an incident dataset. The predictive ability of the proposed method compared to conventional tree-based methods revealed near-perfect predictions of the proposed model on test data (classification accuracy − 0.878 and coefficient of determination − 0.93) for the two outcome variables ACCIDENT and INJURYFREQ. The high predictive power obtained reveals that injuries do not occur in a chaotic fashion, but that underlying patterns and trends exist that can be uncovered and captured via machine learning when applied to sufficiently large datasets. Also, key relationships identified will assist safety managers to understand possible risk combinations that cause accidents; helping to trigger proactive risk mitigation plans. © 2020 Elsevier Ltd
Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to develop a robust and accurate prediction model using machine learning to forecast imminent accidents in power infrastructure projects, facilitating proactive risk mitigation strategies.
Problem: The challenge addressed was the difficulty in optimally eliminating redundant features in machine learning algorithms and finely tuning the parameters to enhance prediction accuracy.
Data: The study used 1,349,239 data points from an incident dataset pertaining to power infrastructure projects.
Methods_Techniques: A particle swarm optimization approach was proposed for both feature selection and parameter tuning of the gradient boosting machine technique.
Results: The results indicated that the proposed method achieved nearly perfect predictions on test data, with a classification accuracy of 0.878 and a coefficient of determination of 0.93 for the outcome variables ACCIDENT and INJURYFREQ. This high predictive power demonstrates that injuries follow identifiable patterns rather than occurring randomly, and that machine learning can successfully capture these patterns when applied to large datasets.

title: A novel classification approach based on context connotative network (CCNet): A case of construction site accidents
authors: Gupta, Aryan Kumar and Sai Pardheev, Chunduru Geetha Venkata and Choudhuri, Sinjana and Das, Souvik and Garg, Ashish and Maiti, J.
abstract: Construction sites are the most hazardous workplace in the world. Occupational safety is one of the high-priority safety concerns across the globe. Among all the sectors, the construction sector contributes towards more hazardous fatalities. Along with a huge loss in manpower, it also causes drastic financial loss. In this study, text mining techniques along with deep neural networks are used for text classification. In detail, GloVe word embeddings with 300 dimensions are employed. We propose the context connotative network (CCNet) for accident causes classification. The dataset taken into account in this research work is referred from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) website. Besides, 5 baseline models namely Logistic Regression (LR), K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Support Vector Machines (SVM), Naive Bayes (NB), and Decision Tree (DT) are trained for comparison with the CCNet model. The results of this research work show that the proposed CCNet model outperforms all the other standard models employed, in respect of the average weighted F1 score metric. Experiment results prove that using GloVe embeddings helped to capture semantic relationships between words and extracting noun and verb phrases helped in boosting the performance of the proposed model. © 2022 Elsevier Ltd
Objectives: The primary goal of this study was to enhance the classification of accident causes in the construction sector using advanced text mining and machine learning techniques.
Problem: The construction industry is one of the most hazardous sectors worldwide, leading to numerous fatalities and significant financial losses due to occupational safety issues. Existing methods for classifying accident causes may not be adequately effective.
Data: The data utilized in this study originates from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) website.
Methods_Techniques: This research employs text mining techniques and deep neural networks specifically. GloVe word embeddings with 300 dimensions were utilized for text classification. A new model named the context connotative network (CCNet) was proposed and compared against five baseline models which include Logistic Regression (LR), K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Support Vector Machines (SVM), Naive Bayes (NB), and Decision Tree (DT).
Results: The findings discovered that the newly proposed CCNet model surpassed the performance of all other standard models in classifying accident causes, as evaluated by the average weighted F1 score metric. The use of GloVe embeddings proved beneficial in capturing semantic relationships, and the extraction of noun and verb phrases contributed significantly to the performance enhancement of the model.

title: Sectoral patterns of accident process for occupational safety using narrative texts of OSHA database
authors: Suh, Yongyoon
objectives: The narrative text analytics has recently focused on identifying an accident process in the various fields of safety such as manufacturing, constructi
abstract: The narrative text analytics has recently focused on identifying an accident process in the various fields of safety such as manufacturing, construction, chemicals, and service. In particular, narrative texts allow finding multiple accident factors and types of accident process including industry, hazard, work activity, and accident result. To present similarity and difference of accident process by categorizing those multiple accident factors shared across industries, identifying sectoral patterns of accidents are useful. In this respect, this study aims to identify the sectoral patterns of accident process using narrative texts information contained in accident reports. For this, the textmining and latent Dirichlet allocation (LDA) algorithms are used to extract topics of accidents and their main factors, matched with class of industries. As a result of the case study for the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) in the United States, the five sectoral patterns of accident process are identified: scale-intensive, facility-intensive, supplier-dominated, market-dominated, and service-dominated patterns. According to these sectoral patterns, managers and policy makers in the fields of safety take a look at the management issues related to the industry, source, activity, and accident result, considering respective characteristics of industrial sites. © 2021 Elsevier Ltd
Objectives: The main purpose of this study is to identify sectoral patterns of accident processes using narrative text information from accident reports.
Problem: The problem addressed is the challenge in identifying and categorizing multiple accident factors and types of accident processes across different industries, which could help in understanding the similarities and differences in accident processes by industry.
Data: The data used in the study consists of narrative texts from accident reports, specifically from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) in the United States.
Methods_Techniques: The methods applied in this research include text mining and Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA) algorithms. These were used to extract topics of accidents and their main factors matched with class of industries.
Results: The study identified five sectoral patterns of accident processes: scale-intensive, facility-intensive, supplier-dominated, market-dominated, and service-dominated patterns. These findings can assist managers and policy makers in the fields of safety to address management issues in relation to industry, source, activity, and accident results, taking into account the specific characteristics of industrial sites.

title: Developing an ensemble predictive safety risk assessment model: Case of Malaysian construction projects
authors: Sadeghi, Haleh and Mohandes, Saeed Reza and Hosseini, M. Reza and Banihashemi, Saeed and Mahdiyar, Amir and Abdullah, Arham
problem: Occupational Health and Safety (OHS)-related injuries are vexing problems for construction projects
abstract: Occupational Health and Safety (OHS)-related injuries are vexing problems for construction projects in developing countries, mostly due to poor managerial-, governmental-, and technical safety-related issues. Though some studies have been conducted on OHS-associated issues in developing countries, research on this topic remains scarce. A review of the literature shows that presenting a predictive assessment framework through machine learning techniques can add much to the field. As for Malaysia, despite the ongoing growth of the construction sector, there has not been any study focused on OHS assessment of workers involved in construction activities. To fill these gaps, an Ensemble Predictive Safety Risk Assessment Model (EPSRAM) is developed in this paper as an effective tool to assess the OHS risks related to workers on construction sites. The developed EPSRAM is based on the integration of neural networks with fuzzy inference systems. To show the effectiveness of the EPSRAM developed, it is applied to several Malaysian construction case projects. This paper contributes to the field in several ways, through: (1) identifying major potential safety risks, (2) determining crucial factors that affect the safety assessment for construction workers, (3) predicting the magnitude of identified safety risks accurately, and (4) predicting the evaluation strategies applicable to the identified risks. It is demonstrated how EPSRAM can provide safety professionals and inspectors concerned with well-being of workers with valuable information, leading to improving the working environment of construction crew members. © 2020 by the authors. Licensee MDPI, Basel, Switzerland.
Objectives: The primary goal of this study was to develop an effective tool, the Ensemble Predictive Safety Risk Assessment Model (EPSRAM), to assess occupational health and safety (OHS) risks for workers on construction sites in Malaysia.
Problem: The study addressed the issue of persistent OHS-related injuries in construction projects within developing countries, particularly due to inadequate management, governmental oversight, and technical safety measures. Additionally, a specific focus was on the lack of research specifically targeting Malaysian construction sites.
Data: The study utilized case projects from various construction sites in Malaysia to apply the EPSRAM and evaluate its effectiveness.
Methods_Techniques: The developed EPSRAM integrated neural networks with fuzzy inference systems to assess the safety risks. This model aimed to identify major safety risks, crucial factors impacting safety assessments, and predict the magnitude and possible mitigation strategies for these risks.
Results: The EPSRAM successfully identified and predicted major potential safety risks and crucial factors affecting construction worker safety. It also provided accurate predictions of the magnitude of these risks and the applicable evaluation strategies, thereby furnishing safety professionals and inspectors with valuable information to enhance the working environment for construction crews.

title: Assessment of construction workers’ perceived risk using physiological data from wearable sensors: A machine learning approach
authors: Lee, By Gaang and Choi, Byungjoo and Jebelli, Houtan and Lee, SangHyun
objectives: Considering that workers' safe or unsafe behaviors are responses to their perceived risk when working, understanding workers' perceived risk is vital
abstract: Considering that workers' safe or unsafe behaviors are responses to their perceived risk when working, understanding workers' perceived risk is vital for safety management in the construction industry. Existing tools for measuring workers' perceived levels of risk mainly rely on post-hoc survey-based assessments, which are limited by their lack of continuous monitoring ability, lack of objectivity, and high cost. To address these limitations, this study develops an automatic method to recognize construction workers’ perceived levels of risk by using physiological signals acquired from wristband-type wearable biosensors in conjunction with a supervised-learning algorithm. The performance of the model was examined with physiological signals acquired from eight construction workers performing their daily work. The model achieved a validation accuracy of 81.2% for distinguishing between low and high levels of perceived risk. This study provides a new means of continuous, objective, and non-invasive method for monitoring construction workers' perceived levels of risk. © 2021 Elsevier Ltd
Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to develop an automatic method for recognizing construction workers' perceived levels of risk using physiological signals and machine learning techniques.
Problem: The study addressed the limitations of existing tools for measuring workers' perceived risk, which suffer from a lack of continuous monitoring, objectivity, and involve high costs.
Data: Physiological signals were collected from eight construction workers using wristband-type wearable biosensors as they performed their daily work tasks.
Methods_Techniques: The study utilized a supervised-learning algorithm to analyze the physiological signals and distinguish between low and high levels of perceived risk among workers.
Results: The developed model achieved a validation accuracy of 81.2% in distinguishing between low and high perceived risk scenarios, offering a new, continuous, objective, and non-invasive method to monitor perceived risk in the construction industry.

title: Decision process for safety based on Bayesian approach
authors: Aissani, Nassima and Mohamed Guitarni, Islam Hadj and Lounis, Zoubida
objectives: Bayesian approach is a quantitative risk analysis technique allowing a probabilistic analysis of dreaded event with their causes and effects. By creat
problem: Bayesian approach is a quantitative risk analysis technique allowing a probabilistic analysis of dre
abstract: Bayesian approach is a quantitative risk analysis technique allowing a probabilistic analysis of dreaded event with their causes and effects. By creating a Bayesian Belief etwork a model knowledge can be developed to predict the studied system evolution. The aim of this method is to estimate a posteriori probability of the dreaded event, their causes and consequences, and gives a developed decisional support tool for risk assessment.In this paper, Bayesian approach will be experimented on safety data of a cement factory in west of Algeria (CFWA). Accident data of 6 years are saved, however some records are not completed or description is not clear generating incompleteness and uncertainty. A conceptual and generic model should be developed with a protocol for assessing the risk of injuries on persons and a computational module which constitute a decisional support system for risk assessment (DSRS). Then, experiment the model and generate many scenarios to understand and create knowledge about causes or conditions that generate those dreaded events. And finally, based on the results of this research, problem areas were determined such as struck by falling objects is a major hazard at cement industry, and convince the staff not to neglect the instructions to wear individual protection equipment (IPE). © 2018 IEEE.
Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to utilize a Bayesian Belief Network to predict the system evolution of a cement factory, estimate the probabilities of various hazardous events, their causes and consequences, and provide a decisional support system for risk assessment.
Problem: The study addresses the challenge of incomplete and unclear accident records over a six-year period at a cement factory, which generates uncertainty in risk assessment processes.
Data: The data used in this study includes six years of accident records from a cement factory in the west of Algeria, although it is noted that some of these records are incomplete or unclear.
Methods_Techniques: The study applied a Bayesian approach to develop a conceptual and generic model that includes a protocol for assessing the risk of injuries and a computational module that acts as a decisional support system for risk assessment. The model was tested by generating various scenarios to analyze causes and conditions leading to hazardous events.
Results: The main findings indicate that falling objects are a significant hazard in the cement industry. The study also highlighted the importance of adhering to safety instructions, specifically the wearing of individual protection equipment, to mitigate risks.

title: Integrated ergonomic and productivity analysis for process improvement of panelised floor manufacturing
authors: Ritter, Chelsea and Barkokebas, Regina Dias and Li, Xinming and Al-Hussein, Mohamed
objectives: Workers in the construction manufacturing industry are often exposed to labour-intensive tasks with ergonomic risks such as awkward body posture, forc
abstract: Workers in the construction manufacturing industry are often exposed to labour-intensive tasks with ergonomic risks such as awkward body posture, forceful exertion, and repetition motion. Due to the increased productivity and increased repetitive motions resulting from improvement initiatives implemented in offsite construction, the investigation of ergonomic risks associated with these changes is needed. In this context, this paper explores an existing panelised floor production line aiming to minimize its ergonomic risks while improving its current productivity rate. Information on human body motion and productivity are extracted from video recordings. The ergonomic risks associated with specific tasks are identified using an existing ergonomic risk assessment tool (i.e., Rapid Entire Body Assessment (REBA)). The information extracted from the simulation model pertaining to ergonomic risks and productivity supports the decision-making process and aids in the prioritization of changes to improve the working environment. © Modeling and Applied Simulation, MAS 2019.All Rights Reserved.
Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to explore an existing panelised floor production line to reduce ergonomic risks and enhance productivity rates.
Problem: The problem addressed in this study is the increased ergonomic risks, such as awkward body postures, forceful exertion, and repetitive motion, faced by workers in the construction manufacturing industry, particularly due to increased productivity and repetitive tasks resulting from offsite construction improvement initiatives.
Data: The data used in this study were derived from video recordings that provided information on human body motion and productivity levels.
Methods_Techniques: The study applied the Rapid Entire Body Assessment (REBA) tool for identifying ergonomic risks associated with specific tasks. Additionally, a simulation model was used to extract information relevant to ergonomic risks and productivity to support decision-making.
Results: The main findings highlighted key ergonomic risks associated with certain tasks and how the information from the ergonomic risk assessment and simulation model can help prioritize changes and improve the working environment and productivity in a construction manufacturing setup.

title: Classifying construction site photos for roof detection
authors: Siddula, Madhuri and Dai, Fei and Ye, Yanfang and Fan, Jianping
abstract: Purpose - Roofing is one of the most dangerous jobs in the construction industry. Due to factors suchas lack of planning, training and use of precaution, roofing contractors and workers continuouslyviolate the fall protection standards enforced by the US Occupational Safety and HealthAdministration. A preferable way to alleviate this situation is automating the process ofnon-compliance checking of safety standards through measurements conducted in site dailyaccumulated videos and photos. As a key component, the purpose of this paper is to devise a method todetect roofs in site images that is indispensable for such automation process. Design/methodology/approach - This method represents roof objects through imagesegmentation and visual feature extraction. The visual features include colour, texture, compactness,contrast and the presence of roof corner. A classification algorithm is selected to use the derivedrepresentation for statistical learning and detection. Findings - The experiments led to detection accuracy of 97.50 per cent, with over 15 per centimprovement in comparison to conventional classifiers, signifying the effectiveness of the proposedmethod. Research limitations/implications - This study did not test on images of roofs in the followingconditions: roofs initially built without apparent appearance (e.g. structural roof framing completed andundergoing the sheathing process) and flat, barrel and dome roofs. From a standpoint of constructionsafety, while the present work is vital, coupling with semantic representation and analysis is still neededto allow for risk analysis of fall violations on roof sites. Originality/value - This study is the first to address roof detection in site images. Its findings providea basis to enable semantic representation of roof site objects of interests (e.g. co-existence andcorrelation among roof site, roofer, guardrail and personal fall arrest system) that is needed to automatethe non-compliance checking of safety standards on roof sites. © Emerald Group Publishing Limited.
Objectives: The main purpose of this study is to devise a method to detect roofs in site images, an essential component for automating non-compliance checking of safety standards in roofing construction.
Problem: The problem addressed is the high risk in the roofing segment of the construction industry, often due to non-compliance with fall protection standards. Automating detection in daily site images and videos could help mitigate this issue.
Data: The study utilized site images that include videos and photos collected daily for detecting roofs and ensuring compliance with safety standards.
Methods_Techniques: The methods applied include image segmentation and visual feature extraction (covering aspects such as color, texture, compactness, contrast, and presence of roof corner) followed by a classification algorithm for statistical learning and detection.
Results: The method realized a roof detection accuracy of 97.50%, representing an over 15% improvement compared to conventional classifiers, demonstrating the effectiveness of the proposed approach. Limitations were noted in not testing on images of roofs under certain conditions like structural roof framing or specific types such as flat, barrel, and dome roofs. Further work is required in semantic representation and analysis for comprehensive risk evaluation.

title: Industrial and occupational ergonomics in the petrochemical process industry: A regression trees approach
authors: Bevilacqua, M. and Ciarapica, F.E. and Giacchetta, G.
objectives: This work is an attempt to apply classification tree methods to data regarding accidents in a medium-sized refinery, so as to identify the important r
abstract: This work is an attempt to apply classification tree methods to data regarding accidents in a medium-sized refinery, so as to identify the important relationships between the variables, which can be considered as decision-making rules when adopting any measures for improvement. The results obtained using the CART (Classification And Regression Trees) method proved to be the most precise and, in general, they are encouraging concerning the use of tree diagrams as preliminary explorative techniques for the assessment of the ergonomic, management and operational parameters which influence high accident risk situations. The Occupational Injury analysis carried out in this paper was planned as a dynamic process and can be repeated systematically. The CART technique, which considers a very wide set of objective and predictive variables, shows new cause-effect correlations in occupational safety which had never been previously described, highlighting possible injury risk groups and supporting decision-making in these areas. The use of classification trees must not, however, be seen as an attempt to supplant other techniques, but as a complementary method which can be integrated into traditional types of analysis. © 2008 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
Objectives: The main goal of this study was to apply classification tree methods to analyze data from accidents in a medium-sized refinery, in order to identify key relationships between variables that can inform decision-making for improvements.
Problem: The study addressed the challenge of understanding the complex relationships between ergonomic, management, and operational parameters that influence high accident risk situations in a refinery setting.
Data: The data utilized in this study included accidents occurring in a medium-sized refinery, focusing on various objective and predictive variables related to occupational safety.
Methods_Techniques: The study applied the CART (Classification And Regression Trees) method to explore and identify new cause-effect correlations in occupational safety, demonstrating its effectiveness as a preliminary explorative technique.
Results: The findings revealed precise cause-effect correlations within the data that had not been previously identified, offering insights into potential injury risk groups. These results support decision-making processes concerning operational safety improvements. Additionally, the study emphasized that the use of classification trees should complement, rather than replace, traditional analysis techniques.

title: Automatic Biomechanical Workload Estimation for Construction Workers by Computer Vision and Smart Insoles
authors: Yu, Yantao and Li, Heng and Umer, Waleed and Dong, Chao and Yang, Xincong and Skitmore, Martin and Wong, Arnold Y. L.
abstract: Construction workers are commonly subject to ergonomic risks due to awkward working postures or lifting/carrying heavy objects. Accordingly, accurate ergonomic assessment is needed to help improve efficiency and reduce risks. However, the diverse and dynamic nature of construction activities makes it difficult to unobtrusively collect worker behavior data for analysis. To address this issue, an automatic workload approach is proposed for the first time to continuously assess worker body joints using image-based three-dimensional (3D) posture capture smart insoles, and biomechanical analysis to provide detailed and accurate assessments based on real data instead of simulation. This approach was tested in an experiment, indicating that the method was able to automatically collect data concerning the workers' 3D posture, estimate external loads, and provide the estimated loads on key body joints with an error rate of 15%. In addition to helping prevent construction workers' ergonomic risks, the method provides a new data collection approach that may benefit various behavior research fields related to construction safety and productivity management. © 2019 American Society of Civil Engineers.
Objectives: The main purpose of this study is to propose an automatic workload approach for continuously assessing worker body joints and providing detailed ergonomic assessments to help reduce risks and improve efficiency in construction activities.
Problem: Construction workers face ergonomic risks due to awkward postures and heavy lifting. The diverse and dynamic nature of construction tasks makes it difficult to unobtrusively collect accurate data on worker behavior for ergonomic analysis.
Data: The data was collected using image-based three-dimensional (3D) posture capture via smart insoles, along with biomechanical analysis to estimate external loads on key body joints.
Methods_Techniques: The study employed a combination of 3D posture capture, smart insoles, and biomechanical analysis to continuously assess worker body joints and estimate external loads. The method provides real data-based ergonomic assessments with a 15% error rate.
Results: The proposed method successfully collected 3D posture data and estimated external loads on key body joints with a 15% error rate. The method offers a new approach for data collection and can benefit various research fields related to construction safety and productivity management.

title: Application of association rule algorithm to industrial safety data mining
authors: Buddhakulsomsiri, Jirachai and Pannakkong, Warut and Nanthavanij, Suebsak
abstract: This article presents an association rule-generation algorithm for mining industrial safety data. Examples of accident data are information about injured workers (e.g., age, gender, work experience), date and time of accidents, and severity level of accidents. The proposed algorithm implements the elementary set concept to generate useful relationships between accidents and worker-related attributes and severity of accidents. The relationships are presented as IF-THEN association rules, where the IF statement(s) include a set of accident condition attributes and the THEN statement(s) include attributes that represent a decision outcome (i.e., accident severity). After the rules are generated, the algorithm applies a user-specified filter and a statistical significance test to identify important rules. The rules that pass the filter and the significance test are then reported in the solution. A case study of using the algorithm to mine real safety data obtained from a selected industry is presented, along with examples of reported rules and their interpretations. Copyright © 2015 Inderscience Enterprises Ltd.
Objectives: The main purpose of the study is to develop an algorithm for generating association rules to mine industrial safety data effectively.
Problem: The challenge addressed is to find useful relationships between worker-related attributes and accident severity to improve workplace safety.
Data: The study used accident data including information on injured workers such as age, gender, and work experience, as well as the date, time, and severity level of accidents.
Methods_Techniques: The study introduced an algorithm based on the elementary set concept to generate IF-THEN association rules relating accident conditions to outcomes like severity. It incorporated a user-specified filter and a statistical significance test to ensure the relevance and importance of the generated rules.
Results: The case study demonstrated that the algorithm successfully mined real safety data and identified significant association rules, which were reported with interpretations, thus showing the potential of this method in enhancing industrial safety analysis.

title: Assessment of occupational risks In Turkish manufacturing systems with data-driven models
authors: Mutlu, Nazli G. and Altuntas, Serkan
problem: Occupational accidents often occur due to a combination of multiple factors depending on the machine
abstract: Occupational accidents often occur due to a combination of multiple factors depending on the machine equipment, working conditions and organizational factors during work. According to the occupational accident statistics of the International Labour Organization, Turkey has ranked 1–7 in fatal occupational accidents in the last 9 years. Occupational accidents in Turkey are a critical problem to solve. The vast majority of occupational accidents in Turkey are experienced in the manufacturing industry. Moreover, the number of studies analyzing occupational accidents in the manufacturing industry is limited in the literature. For this reason, the record of 242,537 occupational accidents in the manufacturing industry between 2013 and 2016 was taken from the Turkey Social Security Institution for this study. As methods of data analysis, feature selection, decision tree analysis and association rule mining were chosen as data mining methods and were applied. As a result of the analysis, it was found that the following 5 factors had an effect on the type of accident in manufacturing systems at a level of 92.40%: material (the equipment used during the accident), special activity, general activity, place (department where the accident occurred) and profession. For these factors, tree models were formed in terms of the accident type, and association rules were obtained for each type of accident. The obtained results are believed to be useful and are practical for use in the development and update of the occupational accident prevention politics of the Turkish Republic National Council for Occupational Health and Security, in the risk analysis and assessment processes of occupational health and security professionals, and in trainings on occupational health and security. © 2019 The Society of Manufacturing Engineers
Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to analyze occupational accidents in Turkey’s manufacturing industry to identify the factors contributing to the types of accidents and to use the findings to support occupational health and safety policies.
Problem: Occupational accidents are a significant issue in Turkey, particularly in the manufacturing industry. The country ranks high in fatal occupational accidents globally, but there is limited literature analyzing these accidents in the manufacturing sector.
Data: The study analyzed data from 242,537 occupational accidents in Turkey’s manufacturing industry between 2013 and 2016, obtained from the Turkey Social Security Institution.
Methods_Techniques: Data mining methods, including feature selection, decision tree analysis, and association rule mining, were applied to identify factors that influenced the type of accidents. Five key factors were identified: material (equipment used), special activity, general activity, place (department), and profession.
Results: The analysis found that these five factors accounted for 92.40% of the variance in accident types. Tree models were developed, and association rules were generated for different types of accidents. The findings are expected to help shape occupational health and safety policies, risk analysis processes, and safety training in Turkey’s manufacturing industry.

title: The construction dust-induced occupational health risk using Monte-Carlo simulation
authors: Tong, Ruipeng and Cheng, Mengzhao and Zhang, Lei and Liu, Meng and Yang, Xiaoyi and Li, Xiaodong and Yin, Wentao
abstract: A probabilistic risk assessment model was developed to explore the health effects of construction dust on the practitioners in the construction industry based on the United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) risk assessment model and the Monte-Carlo simulation method. The health risk was assessed for workers in five zones during the superstructure construction stage of residential projects in Beijing. Health impairment assessment models were applied to translate health risks into disability-adjusted life years (DALYs), which are more intuitive and easy to understand. Sensitivity analysis methods were used to analyse the various exposure parameters and influencing factors that affect the health risk assessment results. The results indicated that workers in the template zone were exposed to the largest health risk, which followed a lognormal distribution of 1.14 × 10−6±9.43 × 10−7, and the probability exceeding 10−6 was more than 40%. The average health risks for workers in the steel, concrete and floor zones were slightly below 10−6, and the workers in the office zone had the lowest health risk. The spearman rank correlation coefficient method and the full factorial designs method were used for a sensitivity analysis and validation. Sensitivity analysis showed that the sensitivities of the average exposure time (AT), exposure duration (ED), exposure frequency (EF) and concentration (C) were larger, while AT and body weight (BW) exhibited a negative sensitivity. Workers in the template and steel zones had the larger health damage, with an average of more than 0.1a. © 2018 Elsevier Ltd
Objectives: The study aimed to develop and apply a probabilistic risk assessment model to evaluate the health effects of construction dust on workers in the construction industry.
Problem: The challenge addressed was assessing the health risks associated with exposure to construction dust during the superstructure construction stage of residential projects.
Data: The study focused on workers in five different zones of residential construction sites in Beijing.
Methods_Techniques: The researchers employed the USEPA risk assessment model and the Monte Carlo simulation method, along with health impairment assessment models to translate risks into disability-adjusted life years (DALYs). Sensitivity analysis methods were also utilized to analyze various exposure parameters and influencing factors.
Results: The findings revealed that workers in the template zone faced the highest health risk, with significant variability in risk levels across different zones. Sensitivity analysis indicated that average exposure time, duration, frequency, and concentration had major influences on health risk assessments, while certain factors like average time and body weight showed negative sensitivity. Workers in the template and steel zones experienced the most substantial health damage.

title: Text mining based safety risk assessment and prediction of occupational accidents in a steel plant
authors: Sarkar, Sobhan and Vinay, Sammangi and Maiti, Jhareswar
abstract: Occupational accidents are a serious threat to any organization. Occupational accidents in steel industry sector remain a threat as workforce is exposed to different kinds of hazards due to the workplace characteristics. In this study, a unique method is proposed by developing a text mining based prediction model using fault tree analysis (FTA), and Bayesian Network (BN). Free unstructured accident dataset for a period of four years has been used in this study. Text mining approach results in finding the basic events concerning each of primary causes. The basic events, in turn, are utilized in building FT and BN diagram that could predict the occurrence of accidents attributable to different primary causes. The model, so developed, can be considered adequate with 87.5% accuracy. Furthermore, sensitivity analysis is performed for the validation of the model. © 2016 IEEE.
Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to develop a prediction model using text mining to forecast occupational accidents in the steel industry.
Problem: The study addresses the persistent threat of occupational accidents in the steel industry, where the workforce is exposed to various hazards inherent to their working environment.
Data: The data used in this study consisted of a free unstructured accident dataset covering a period of four years.
Methods_Techniques: The research utilized fault tree analysis (FTA) and Bayesian Network (BN) alongside text mining techniques to analyze the data and develop a prediction model that identifies basic events linked to primary accident causes.
Results: The prediction model demonstrated an accuracy of 87.5%. Additionally, sensitivity analysis was conducted to validate the model, confirming its adequacy in predicting occupational accidents based on different primary causes.

title: Data mining for occupational injuries in the Taiwan construction industry
authors: Liao, Chia-Wen and Perng, Yeng-Horng
abstract: There is a higher rate of occupational injury in the construction industry than most other industries on average. However, steps can be taken to reduce worker risk through effective injury prevention strategies. In this article, association rule mining is employed in identifying the characteristics of occupational injuries in the construction industry. Accident reports during the period 1999-2004 are extracted from case reports of the Northern Region Inspection Office of the Council of Labor Affairs of Taiwan. In addition to general factors, several factors related to weather conditions are included in this article. The results show that there are some patterns of occupational injuries in the construction industry. The effect of rain on the occurrence of fatalities is of great significance. Proposed inspection plans should be in accordance with the type of construction and environmental evaluation. The findings identified in this article provide a direction for more effective inspection strategies and injury prevention programs. © 2007 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to identify the characteristics of occupational injuries in the construction industry and to provide direction for more effective inspection strategies and injury prevention programs.
Problem: The study addressed the problem of a higher rate of occupational injuries in the construction industry compared to other industries, focusing particularly on how environmental factors like weather conditions influence these injuries.
Data: The study used accident reports from the period 1999-2004, which were sourced from the Northern Region Inspection Office of the Council of Labor Affairs of Taiwan.
Methods_Techniques: Association rule mining was employed as the primary method to analyze the characteristics and patterns of occupational injuries in the construction industry.
Results: The study found identifiable patterns of occupational injuries in the construction industry, with the impact of rain on the occurrence of fatalities highlighted as particularly significant. These findings support the development of tailored inspection plans based on the type of construction work and environmental conditions.

title: Identifying convergence fields and technologies for industrial safety: LDA-based network analysis
authors: Song, Bomi and Suh, Yongyoon
objectives: As industrial systems expand and complex systems are developed, it is no longer effective to minimize hazards and risks for industrial safety using th
problem: As industrial systems expand and complex systems are developed, it is no longer effective to minimiz
abstract: As industrial systems expand and complex systems are developed, it is no longer effective to minimize hazards and risks for industrial safety using the technological solutions limited to a single industry. Thus, to resolve complicated problems, safety technology has been developed by promoting technology innovation and convergence. In this respect, this study aims at monitoring major safety fields and technologies through patent analysis to identify the trends in technology development that prevent the risks of various industrial systems. Patent information is effectively used for analyzing technology descriptions, which include the purpose and newness of technology. Using this patent information, we propose the major safety fields and related technology keywords using the following two techniques: (1) latent Dirichlet allocation (LDA), which aims to extract the latent topics and main keywords contained in documents, and (2) network analysis, which is useful for monitoring change patterns and relations. Further, the convergence trajectories of safety technology are identified to provide insights about the technology trends in safety fields. The results are expected to enable safety managers and engineers to effectively find relevant technology trends for reducing hazardous factors. © 2018 Elsevier Inc.
Objectives: The main purpose of the study is to monitor major safety fields and technologies via patent analysis, aiming to identify technology development trends that mitigate risks in various industrial systems.
Problem: The challenge addressed is the inadequacy of single-industry technological solutions in minimizing hazards and risks in the context of expanding industrial systems and the development of complex systems.
Data: The study utilized patent information, which includes descriptions of technology detailing its purpose and novelty.
Methods_Techniques: The study applied two main techniques: latent Dirichlet allocation (LDA) to extract latent topics and main keywords from documents, and network analysis to monitor change patterns and relationships in safety technology.
Results: The findings highlight the convergence trajectories of safety technology, providing insights into the current trends of safety-related technologies. This information is expected to help safety managers and engineers effectively identify relevant technology trends for reducing hazardous factors in industrial environments.

title: Advanced application of text analytics in MSHA metal and nonmetal fatality reports
authors: Raj, K.V. and Tarshizi, E.K.
abstract: Advanced data science techniques have been applied in a verity of fields to improve health and safety and reduce accident and fatality rates. Similar to other industries, the mining industry requires the adoption and implementation of modern research methods to continue boosting safety in mine operations. Text analytics, in general, is one of the essential methods used to analyze unstructured data that is in text format. Using text mining and Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques to extract patterns with incidents and identify insightful information from contents and reports is extremely valuable to produce actionable recommendations and strategies for applying text mining and NLP to accident text data. In this research investigation, advanced text mining techniques and NLP were applied to the U.S. Mine Safety and Health Administration (MSHA) final fatality reports in metal and nonmetal operations (surface and underground) to perform preprocessing, Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA), and various statistics to discover insightful word relation patterns in the reports. For this purpose, the final fatality reports from 2010 through 2017 were collected and cleaned. In addition, topic modeling was done to group the reports with similar underlying themes or topics. Copyright © 2020 by SME
Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to apply text mining and Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques to mine accident data, aiming to extract patterns and insights that could lead to actionable recommendations for improving safety in the mining industry.
Problem: The study addressed the challenge of analyzing unstructured text data from accident reports to enhance safety operations in the mining sector, where there is a critical need to reduce accidents and fatalities.
Data: The data utilized in the study consisted of the U.S. Mine Safety and Health Administration (MSHA) final fatality reports from metal and nonmetal mining operations (both surface and underground) spanning the years 2010 through 2017.
Methods_Techniques: The research employed advanced text mining techniques and NLP for preprocessing and Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA) of the accident reports. It also included various statistical methods to uncover meaningful word relation patterns and topic modeling to cluster the reports based on similar themes or topics.
Results: The main findings of the study were not specified in detail in the abstract. However, it is implied that insightful information and patterns were successfully extracted from the text data, which could potentially inform safety improvement strategies in the mining industry.

title: Construction site accident analysis using text mining and natural language processing techniques
authors: Zhang, Fan and Fleyeh, Hasan and Wang, Xinru and Lu, Minghui
abstract: Workplace safety is a major concern in many countries. Among various industries, construction sector is identified as the most hazardous work place. Construction accidents not only cause human sufferings but also result in huge financial loss. To prevent reoccurrence of similar accidents in the future and make scientific risk control plans, analysis of accidents is essential. In construction industry, fatality and catastrophe investigation summary reports are available for the past accidents. In this study, text mining and natural language process (NLP) techniques are applied to analyze the construction accident reports. To be more specific, five baseline models, support vector machine (SVM), linear regression (LR), K-nearest neighbor (KNN), decision tree (DT), Naive Bayes (NB) and an ensemble model are proposed to classify the causes of the accidents. Besides, Sequential Quadratic Programming (SQP) algorithm is utilized to optimize weight of each classifier involved in the ensemble model. Experiment results show that the optimized ensemble model outperforms rest models considered in this study in terms of average weighted F1 score. The result also shows that the proposed approach is more robust to cases of low support. Moreover, an unsupervised chunking approach is proposed to extract common objects which cause the accidents based on grammar rules identified in the reports. As harmful objects are one of the major factors leading to construction accidents, identifying such objects is extremely helpful to mitigate potential risks. Certain limitations of the proposed methods are discussed and suggestions and future improvements are provided. © 2018 Elsevier B.V.
Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to analyze construction accident reports to prevent the reoccurrence of similar accidents and develop more effective scientific risk control plans.
Problem: The problem addressed in this study centers around the high rate of hazards in the construction industry, leading to significant human sufferings and financial losses.
Data: The data used in the study consisted of fatality and catastrophe investigation summary reports from past construction accidents.
Methods_Techniques: The study applied text mining and natural language processing (NLP) techniques. Five baseline models (Support Vector Machine (SVM), Linear Regression (LR), K-nearest Neighbor (KNN), Decision Tree (DT), and Naive Bayes (NB)), along with an ensemble model, were used to classify the causes of the accidents. The Sequential Quadratic Programming (SQP) algorithm was utilized to optimize the weight of each classifier in the ensemble model. Additionally, an unsupervised chunking approach based on grammar rules was used to identify common objects causing the accidents.
Results: The optimized ensemble model outperformed the other models in terms of the average weighted F1 score, indicating it was more effective in classification tasks, specifically in cases of low support. The study also successfully identified common hazardous objects in the construction accidents, aiding in risk mitigation. Limitations were acknowledged and suggestions for future improvements were discussed.

title: Developing ambient support technology for risk management in the mining industry
authors: Lindgren, Helena and Burström, Lage and Järvholm, Bengt
abstract: There is a major goal in the mining industry to reduce risks and maintain health in work environments. Moreover, the industry is obliged to monitor the risks in work environment as well as employers’ health statuses. The potentials in using ambient information for the purpose to reduce risks, prevent work-related injuries and monitor health in individuals has been explored. Applications tailored to the individual are being developed to aid the worker in mining or mining-related work environments in valuing the risks of their work situation and create awareness in the individual about how he or she can decrease risks for primarily physical damages. The purpose is to encourage the worker to act upon the level of risk for injuries, and upon the new insights the worker gain from the applications. The identified opportunities for and obstacles to integrating ambient information in these health applications are discussed. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2014.
Objectives: The main goal of the study was to explore the use of ambient information to reduce risks, prevent work-related injuries, and monitor health in the mining industry.
Problem: The study addresses the challenges in monitoring risks in work environments and employers’ health statuses in the mining industry.
Data: The study does not specify the particular data sets used, but it involves the exploration of ambient information relevant to miners' work environments and their health monitoring.
Methods_Techniques: The study developed applications tailored to individuals working in mining environments. These applications help assess the risks in their specific work situations and aim to increase awareness about reducing physical damage risks.
Results: The main findings include the identification of opportunities for and obstacles to integrating ambient information into health applications for miners. This integration can potentially enhance the safety and health monitoring in the mining sector.

title: Integrating data governance and big data with business processes
authors: Soares, Sunil
abstract: The article maps data governance policies to a simple process to monitor oil field sensor data. Oil and gas companies install sensors on facilities as well as the seabed to monitor production, the state of the facility, health and safety, and adherence to environmental regulations. Companies may also install sensors on the seabed to monitor environmental conditions such as flow, temperature, and turbidity. Turbidity is a measurement of water quality based on the cloudiness of water caused by individual particles that might not be visible to the naked eye. Oil and gas companies also create dashboards to monitor energy production across facilities. Oil and gas companies create common operations centers so they can monitor production from a central location. Environmental sensors may be in operation before, during, and after the operating life of the platform.
Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to present a systematic approach for mapping data governance policies to a straightforward process specifically designed to monitor sensor data in oil fields.
Problem: The study addressed the challenge of effectively managing and monitoring vast amounts of sensor data collected in oil and gas facilities, which is critical for production monitoring, facility maintenance, health and safety, and compliance with environmental regulations.
Data: The data used in this study included sensor data from oil and gas facilities and the seabed, monitoring various parameters such as production levels, facility status, and environmental conditions like flow, temperature, and turbidity.
Methods_Techniques: The study applied data governance policies and developed a process that integrates these policies with the operation of monitoring systems, likely involving the use of dashboards and common operations centers to centralize data monitoring.
Results: The main findings highlighted the effectiveness of the described process in improving the monitoring of energy production and environmental conditions, thereby enhancing overall operational efficiency and regulatory compliance. The results showcased a model for how oil and gas companies can strategically manage sensor data through centralized systems.

title: Big data visualization for occupational health and security problem in oil and gas industry
authors: Trevisan, Daniela Gorski and Sanchez-Pi, Nayat and Marti, Luis and Bicharra Garcia, Ana Cristina
problem: Association rule learning is a popular and well-researched set of methods for discovering interestin
abstract: Association rule learning is a popular and well-researched set of methods for discovering interesting relations between entities in large databases in real-world problems. In this regard, an intelligent offshore oil industry environment is a very complex scenario and Occupational Health and Security (OHS) is a priority issue as it is an important factor to reduce the number of accidents and incidents records. In the oil industry, there exist standards to identify and record workplace accidents and incidents in order to provide guiding means on prevention efforts, indicating specific failures or reference, means of correction of conditions or circumstances that culminated in accident. OHS’s employees are in charge of analyzing the mined rules to extract knowledge. In most of cases these users has two main challenges during this process: (i) to explore the measures of interestingness (confidence, lift, support, etc.) and (ii) to understand and analyze the large number of association rules. In this sense, an intuitive visualization of mined rules becomes a key component in a decision-making process. In this paper, we propose a novel visualization of spatio-temporal rules that provides the big picture about risk analysis in a real world environment. Our main contribution lies in an interactive visualization of accident interpretations by means of well-defined spatio-temporal constraints, in the oil industry domain. © Springer International Publishing Switzerland 2015.
Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to propose a novel visualization method for spatio-temporal rules to aid in risk analysis within an offshore oil industry environment, focusing on Occupational Health and Security (OHS).
Problem: The study addressed the challenges faced by OHS employees in the offshore oil industry, particularly in exploring measures of interestingness in association rules (such as confidence, lift, support) and in handling the large volume of association rules generated during data analysis.
Data: The data used involved standards for recording workplace accidents and incidents within the offshore oil industry, which serve as a basis for analysis and prevention efforts.
Methods_Techniques: The study employed association rule learning to mine data and discover relations between different entities. An interactive visualization technique was developed to represent the spatio-temporal distribution of accidents, enhancing the interpretability of the mined rules.
Results: The main result was the creation of an interactive visualization tool for spatio-temporal rules, designed to provide a comprehensive overview of risk analysis and facilitate more effective decision-making in the oil industry domain. This tool helps in interpreting accident data with a focus on spatial and temporal constraints.

title: Selecting nanoparticle properties to mitigate risks to workers and the public - A machine learning modeling framework to compare pulmonary toxicity risks of nanomaterials
authors: Gernand, Jeremy M. and Casman, Elizabeth A.
objectives: Due to their size and unique chemical properties, nanomaterials have the potential to interact with living organisms in novel ways, leading to a spect
problem: Due to their size and unique chemical properties, nanomaterials have the potential to interact with
abstract: Due to their size and unique chemical properties, nanomaterials have the potential to interact with living organisms in novel ways, leading to a spectrum of negative consequences. Though a relatively new materials science, already nanomaterial variants in the process of becoming too numerous to be screened for toxicity indivi dually by traditional and expensive animal testing. As with conventional pollutants, the resulting backlog of untested new materials means that interim industry and regulatory risk management measures may be mismatched to the actual risk. The ability to minimize toxicity risk from a nanomaterial during the product or system design phase would simplify the risk assessment process and contribute to increased worker and consumer safety. Some attempts to address this problem have been made, primarily analyzing data from in vitro experiments, which are of limited predictive value for the effects on whole organisms. The existing data on the toxicity of inhaled nanomaterials in animal models is sparse in comparison to the number of potential factors that may contribute to or aggravate nanomaterial toxicity, limiting the power of conventional statistical analysis to detect property/toxicity relationships. This situation is exacerbated by the fact that exhaustive chemical and physical characterization of all nanomaterial attributes in these studies is rare, due to resource or equipment constraints and dissimilar investigator priorities. This paper presents risk assessment models developed through a meta-analysis of in vivo nanomaterial rodentinhalational toxicity studies. We apply machine learning techniques including regression trees and the related ensemble method, random forests in order to determine the relative contribution of different physical and chemical attributes on observed toxicity. These methods permit the use of data records with missing information without substituting presumed values and can reveal complex data relationships even in nonlinear contexts or conditional situations. Based on this analysis, we present a predictive risk model for the severity of inhaled nanomaterial toxicity based on a given set of nanomaterial attributes. This model reveals the anticipated change in the expected toxic response to choices of nanomaterial design (such as physical dimensions or chemical makeup). This methodology is intended to aid nanomaterial designers in identifying nanomaterial attributes that contribute to toxicity, giving them the opportunity to substitute safer variants while continuing to meet functional objectives. Findings from this analysis indicate that carbon nanotube (CNT) impurities explain at most 30% of the variance pulmonary toxicity as measured by polymorphonuclear neutrophils (PMN) count. Titanium dioxide nanoparticle size and aggregation affected the observed toxic response by less than ±10%. Difference in observed effects for a group of metal oxide nanoparticle associated with differences in Gibbs Free Energy on lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) concentrations amount to only 4% to the total variance. Other chemical descriptors of metal oxides were unimportant. Copyright © 2013 by ASME.
Objectives: The main goal of this study is to develop risk assessment models that predict the severity of inhaled nanomaterial toxicity, enabling designers to identify harmful attributes and opt for safer alternatives while achieving their functional objectives.
Problem: The study addresses the challenge of the growing number of nanomaterials, which are too numerous to test individually for toxicity through traditional animal testing. This has created a backlog of untested materials, complicating effective risk management in industry and regulation due to mismatches between actual risks and interim measures.
Data: The study utilized data from in vivo nanomaterial rodentinhalational toxicity studies, specifically examining the toxicity of inhaled nanomaterials in animal models.
Methods_Techniques: The researchers applied machine learning techniques, including regression trees and the ensemble method of random forests. These techniques were chosen for their ability to handle data records with missing information and to uncover complex relationships in data, even in nonlinear or conditional scenarios.
Results: The predictive risk model developed in the study revealed that carbon nanotube (CNT) impurities can account for up to 30% of the variance in pulmonary toxicity, while titanium dioxide nanoparticle size and aggregation influenced the toxic response by less than ±10%. Additionally, differences in Gibbs Free Energy on lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) concentrations in metal oxide nanoparticles accounted for only 4% of the total variance in observed effects, with other chemical descriptors of metal oxides being deemed unimportant.

title: A Risk Estimation Approach based on Deep Learning in Shipbuilding Industry
authors: Choi, Youhee and Park, Jeong-Ho and Jang, Byungtae
abstract: Shipbuilding industry is one of the most hazardous industries. To reduce accidents, various safety policies and practices have been established and recommended to obey. Despite workers being made aware of risk associated with not following these practices, many workers do not follow these practices for various reasons such as inconvenience of wearing a personal safety equipment, increase of cost, insufficient working time, and so on. In addition, there are many cases that workers carry out a task or pass through without knowing risk of the task or risk of the area to be worked. It is difficult for each individual worker to know various surrounding circumstances, and there are also limitations in that safety supervisors play a role of safety management for all worksites. Therefore, we propose an automated risk estimation approach to support identifying hazardous zones and estimating risk by verifying whether safety measures are performed for the identified hazardous zone based on deep learning method. © 2019 IEEE.
Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to propose an automated risk estimation approach for identifying hazardous zones and estimating risk in the shipbuilding industry using deep learning methods.
Problem: The study addressed the issue of frequent non-compliance to safety practices among workers in the shipbuilding industry, despite existing safety policies, due to various reasons like inconvenience and lack of awareness about the risks associated with specific tasks or areas.
Data: The abstract does not specify the exact data used for the study. However, the study likely utilized data related to workers' compliance with safety measures and the environmental conditions of the shipbuilding sites.
Methods_Techniques: The study applied deep learning methods to develop an approach for automatically identifying hazardous zones and estimating risks, thereby checking whether safety measures were adequately carried out in these zones.
Results: The main outcome of the study was the development of an automated system capable of identifying hazardous zones and assessing compliance with safety measures to estimate risks, potentially leading to enhanced safety management in the shipbuilding industry.

title: Evaluation of wearable sensors to quantify construction workers muscle force: An ergonomic analysis
authors: Jahanbanifar, Shahin and Akhavian, Reza
abstract: Construction industry has one of the highest rates of bodily injuries including serious Work-related Musculoskeletal Disorders (WMSDs). The Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) identifies force level as a risk indicator associated with WMSDs. Without direct measurement, quantifying the force exerted during a given task performed by workers is difficult, if not impossible. Therefore, an indirect and non-intrusive way of identifying excessive force applied during physical tasks can effectively reduce the risk of WMSD injuries. In this research, a series of physical activities involving pushing and pulling are simulated by the research team in laboratory-scale experiments. The exerted force is measured using a work simulator tool and accelerometer data is collected from a smartphone sensor affixed on the working arm. Artificial Neural Network is trained with the accelerometer data and the force levels. Testing results indicate that the trained model can predict the force level with over 87.5% accuracy. © 2018 IEEE
Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to find an indirect and non-intrusive method to quantify the force exerted by construction workers during tasks to potentially reduce the incidence of Work-related Musculoskeletal Disorders (WMSDs).
Problem: The problem addressed is the challenge in measuring the force level exerted by construction workers during tasks, which is essential to assess the risk of WMSDs, as direct measurement is often difficult or impossible.
Data: The data used in the study included accelerometer data collected from a smartphone sensor attached to the working arm of individuals while they performed simulated pushing and pulling tasks in a laboratory setting.
Methods_Techniques: The methods involved simulated laboratory-scale experiments to measure exerted force using a work simulator tool. An Artificial Neural Network (ANN) was then trained with the collected accelerometer data and the measured force levels.
Results: The primary finding was that the ANN model could predict the force level with over 87.5% accuracy, demonstrating the effectiveness of using accelerometer data in assessing force exertion in construction tasks.

title: Assessment of construction fatalities to predict cause factors by neural network analysis
authors: Thakur, Kaveri A. and Sawhney, Rapinder and Balestrassi, Pedro P.
abstract: The number of fatalities in construction industry is the third highest among the nine major industrial categories. The University of Tennessee, Construction Industry Research and Policy Center (CIRPC) houses the most comprehensive OSHA (Occupational Safety and Health Administration) fatality case file collection. A review of this database indicates that there is both a lack of relevant information and an inability to utilize current database in a predictive manner to impact the number of fatalities. This paper uses Artificial Neural Networks (ANN) to predict the probability of fatal accidents in presence of a combination of contributing factors. A set of significant contributing factors are identified by performing contingency analysis for each contributing factor versus fatal accidents. The results show that ANN model predicts approximately 83% of variation. Contingency analysis of categorical variables show that some factors; namely source of accident, environmental factors, end-use, state have more influence on fatality cause than others. In addition, a predictive model based on ANN is proposed to gauge the probability of fatal accidents and advocate event based safety programs to support primary goals of OSHA.
Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to use Artificial Neural Networks (ANN) to predict the probability of fatal accidents in the construction industry based on various contributing factors, and propose a predictive model to support event-based safety programs aligning with the primary goals of OSHA.
Problem: The study addresses the problem of high fatality rates in the construction industry and the challenges in utilizing existing databases to predict and mitigate these accidents effectively.
Data: The data used in this study was sourced from the comprehensive OSHA fatality case file collection maintained by the Construction Industry Research and Policy Center at the University of Tennessee.
Methods_Techniques: The study employed Artificial Neural Networks (ANN) and contingency analysis to identify significant contributing factors to fatal accidents and predict the variation in these accidents.
Results: The ANN model successfully predicted approximately 83% of the variation in fatal accidents. The contingency analysis revealed that certain factors such as the source of the accident, environmental conditions, end-use, and the state had a significant influence on the causes of fatalities.

title: Deep analytics for workplace risk and disaster management
authors: Dalal, S. and Bassu, D.
objectives: We discuss dynamic real-time analysis from multimodal data fusion for contextual risk identification to generate 'risk maps' for the workplace, result
problem: We discuss dynamic real-time analysis from multimodal data fusion for contextual risk identification
abstract: We discuss dynamic real-time analysis from multimodal data fusion for contextual risk identification to generate 'risk maps' for the workplace, resulting in timely identification of hazards and associated risk mitigation. It includes new machine/deep learning, analytics, methods, and its applications that deal with the unconventional data collected from pictures, videos, documents, mobile apps, sensors/Internet of Things, Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) rules, and Building Information Model (BIM) Models. Specifically, we describe a number of advances and challenges in this field with applications of computer vision, natural language processing, and sensor data analysis. Applications include automated cause identification, damage prevention, and disaster recovery using current and historical claims data and other public data. The methods developed can be applied to any given situation with different groups of people, including first responders. Finally, we discuss some of the important nontechnical challenges related to business practicality, privacy, and industry regulations. © 1957-2012 IBM.
Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to analyze multimodal data in real-time to produce 'risk maps' for identifying workplace hazards efficiently, ultimately aiding in risk mitigation.
Problem: The challenge addressed was the effective and timely identification of risks in the workplace, leveraging the vast amount of diverse data available.
