Data: The data used in the study included pictures, videos, documents, mobile app data, sensor/Internet of Things (IoT) data, Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) rules, and Building Information Model (BIM) Models.
Methods_Techniques: The study employed new machine learning and deep learning analytics, along with methods applicable to unconventional data sources. Techniques included computer vision, natural language processing (NLP), and sensor data analysis.
Results: Key findings included the development of methods for automated cause identification, damage prevention, and disaster recovery using both current and historical claims data, along with other public data sources. These methods are adaptable to various scenarios and different populations, including first responders. Additionally, the study highlighted significant non-technical challenges related to business practicality, privacy, and industry regulations.

title: Use of neural networks to identify safety prevention priorities in agro-manufacturing operations within commercial grain elevators
authors: Kakhki, Fatemeh Davoudi and Freeman, Steven A. and Mosher, Gretchen A.
objectives: The grain handling industry plays a significant role in U.S. agriculture by storing, distributing, and processing a variety of agricultural commoditie
abstract: The grain handling industry plays a significant role in U.S. agriculture by storing, distributing, and processing a variety of agricultural commodities. Commercial grain elevators are hazardous agro-manufacturing work environments where workers are prone to severe injuries, due to the nature of the activities and workplace. Safety incidents in agro-manufacturing operations generally arise from a combination of factors, rather than a single cause, therefore, research on occupational incidents must look deeper into identifying the underlying causes, through the application of advanced analyses methods. In occupational safety, it is possible to estimate and predict probability of safety risks through developing artificial neural network predictive models. Due to the significance of safety risk assessment in the design and prioritization of effective prevention measures, this study aimed at classifying and predicting causes of occupational incidents in grain elevator agro-manufacturing operations in the Midwest region of the United States. Workers' compensation claims data, from 2008 to 2016, were utilized for training multilayer perceptron (MLP) and radial basis function (RBF) neural networks. Both MLP and RBF models could predict the probability of safety risks with a high overall accuracy of 60%, 61%. Based on values of AUC (area under the curve) from the ROC (receiving operating charts), both models predicted the probability of individual safety risks with a high accuracy rate of between 71.5% and 99.2%. In addition, sensitivity analysis showed that nature of injury is the most significant determinant of safety risks probability, along with type of injury. The novelty of this study is the use of the artificial neural network methodology to analyze multi-level causes of occupational incidents as the sources of safety risks in bulk storage facilities. The results confirm that artificial neural networks are useful in safety risk estimation, and identifying the incidents' risk factors. The implementation of safety measures in grain elevators can help in preventing occupational injuries, saving lives, and reducing the occurrence and severity of such incidents in industrial work environments. © 2019 by the authors. Licensee MDPI, Basel, Switzerland.
Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to classify and predict the causes of occupational incidents within grain elevator agro-manufacturing operations in the Midwest region of the United States.
Problem: The problem addressed in this study was the high number of severe injuries in commercial grain elevators due to the hazardous nature of the work environment and activities.
Data: The data utilized in this study encompassed workers' compensation claims from the years 2008 to 2016.
Methods_Techniques: The study employed multilayer perceptron (MLP) and radial basis function (RBF) neural networks to train models that predict the probability of safety risks.
Results: Both MLP and RBF models achieved a general prediction accuracy of 60% and 61%, respectively, and attained high accuracy rates (71.5% to 99.2%) in predicting individual safety risks based on the area under the curve (AUC) of the receiving operating charts (ROC). Sensitivity analysis identified the nature and type of injury as significant determinants of safety risk probabilities. The study showed the effectiveness of using artificial neural networks for safety risk estimation and identifying risk factors in occupational environments.

title: Integration of safety risk data with highway construction schedules
authors: Esmaeili, Behzad and Hallowell, Matthew
abstract: The construction industry is characterized by a relatively high injury and illness rate compared to other industries. Within the construction industry, the highway construction and maintenance sector is one of the most dangerous. To improve safety in this sector, proactive methods of safety improvement and reliable risk data are needed. The safety risk quantification is the first step towards integrating safety data into design and planning. To enhance the current preconstruction safety practices, safety risks of highway construction and maintenance tasks were quantified and a decision support system was developed and tested that integrates safety risk data into the project schedules. Relative safety risks were quantified for 25 common highway construction tasks using the Delphi method. To ensure valid and reliable results, experts were selected according to rigorous requirements and multiple controls were employed to decrease cognitive biases. The data were incorporated into a decision support system called Scheduled-based Safety Risk Assessment and Management (SSRAM) that facilitates integration of safety risk data with project schedules. The resulting data-driven system produces predictive plots of safety risk over time based on the temporal and spatial interactions among concurrent activities. To test the utility of the decision support system and the validity of the underlying risk data, the system was tested on 11 active case study projects in the US. It was found that the database and associated decision support tool produce accurate and reliable risk forecasts that increase the viability of existing safety preconstruction activities. © 2013 Taylor and Francis Group, LLC.
Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to enhance safety in highway construction and maintenance by integrating safety risk data into preconstruction planning and by developing a decision support system.
Problem: The study addressed the challenge of high injury and illness rates within the highway construction and maintenance sector, which is notably dangerous compared to other areas in construction.
Data: The data used included quantified safety risks for 25 common highway construction tasks, obtained using the Delphi method and from testing the decision support system on 11 active case study projects in the US.
Methods_Techniques: The study utilized the Delphi method to quantify safety risks and developed a decision support system called Scheduled-based Safety Risk Assessment and Management (SSRAM). This system integrates safety risk data with project schedules and utilizes controls to decrease cognitive biases among the expert participants.
Results: The findings indicate that the decision support system, along with the database of quantified risks, provides accurate and reliable risk forecasts, enhancing the effectiveness of preconstruction safety activities.

title: Developing a risk assessment model for construction safety
authors: Fung, Ivan W.H. and Tam, Vivian W.Y. and Lo, Tommy Y. and Lu, Lori L.H.
problem: Problems on occupational health and safety are commonly occurred in the construction industry, inclu
abstract: Problems on occupational health and safety are commonly occurred in the construction industry, including falling of materials or person from height, stepping on objects and injured by hand tools. Key of dealing with project safety and risk assessment in construction industry is important, thus, way on doing assessment and liability of assessment are necessary for all professionals. However, it is found that those professionals prone to heavily rely on their own experiences and knowledge on decision making on risk assessment, which lack of a systematic approach and lack of ways to check the reliability of the decisions. This paper investigates the need for people involved in construction to take systematic and effective risk assessments for different trades. 14 common types of trades, accidents, and accident causes are explored, in addition to suitable risk assessment methods and criteria. A Risk Assessment Model (RAM) is then developed for assessing risk levels as various project stages with various work trades. A case study is used to prove the workability and reliability of the developed RAM in the practical industry. The developed RAM is found to be benefit for predicting high-risk construction activities and thus preventing accidents occurred based on a set of historical accident data. © 2009 Elsevier Ltd and IPMA.
Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to investigate the necessity for professionals in the construction industry to conduct systematic and effective risk assessments across different trades.
Problem: The study addressed the issue that construction professionals often rely heavily on personal experience and knowledge when making decisions about risk assessment, lacking a systematic approach and means to verify the reliability of these decisions.
Data: The study utilized historical accident data relevant to the construction industry to analyze and test the developed Risk Assessment Model (RAM).
Methods_Techniques: The study explored 14 common types of construction trades, accidents, and their causes. It developed a Risk Assessment Model (RAM) that evaluates risk levels at various project stages and for different work trades, employing a case study to validate the model's effectiveness and reliability.
Results: The findings indicated that the developed RAM was effective in predicting high-risk construction activities, thereby aiding in the prevention of accidents. The model demonstrated workability and reliability when applied in an industry setting.

title: Analyzing Arizona OSHA Injury Reports Using Unsupervised Machine Learning
authors: Chokor, Abbas and Naganathan, Hariharan and Chong, Wai K. and Asmar, Mounir El
objectives: As the construction continue to be a leading industry in the number of injuries and fatalities annually, several organizations and agencies are workin
abstract: As the construction continue to be a leading industry in the number of injuries and fatalities annually, several organizations and agencies are working avidly to ensure the number of injuries and fatalities is minimized. The Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) is one such effort to assure safe and healthful working conditions for working men and women by setting and enforcing standards and by providing training, outreach, education and assistance. Given the large databases of OSHA historical events and reports, a manual analysis of the fatality and catastrophe investigations content is a time consuming and expensive process. This paper aims to evaluate the strength of unsupervised machine learning and Natural Language Processing (NLP) in supporting safety inspections and reorganizing accidents database on a state level. After collecting construction accident reports from the OSHA Arizona office, the methodology consists of preprocessing the accident reports and weighting terms in order to apply a data-driven unsupervised K-Means-based clustering approach. The proposed method classifies the collected reports in four clusters, each reporting a type of accident. The results show the construction accidents in the state of Arizona to be caused by falls (42.9%), struck by objects (34.3%), electrocutions (12.5%), and trenches collapse (10.3%). The findings of this research empower state and local agencies with a customized presentation of the accidents fitting their regulations and weather conditions. What is applicable to one climate might not be suitable for another; therefore, such rearrangement of the accidents database on a state based level is a necessary prerequisite to enhance the local safety applications and standards. © 2016 The Authors.
Objectives: The main purpose of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of unsupervised machine learning and Natural Language Processing (NLP) in assisting with safety inspections and organizing accident databases at a state level.
Problem: The problem addressed is the challenge of manually analyzing large databases of occupational safety and health reports, specifically from the construction industry, which is both time-consuming and costly.
Data: The data used in the study includes construction accident reports collected from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Arizona office.
Methods_Techniques: The methodology employed involves preprocessing the accident reports, weighting terms, and applying a data-driven unsupervised K-Means-based clustering approach to classify the reports into four different types of accidents.
Results: The study found that the construction accidents in Arizona were predominantly caused by falls (42.9%), followed by being struck by objects (34.3%), electrocutions (12.5%), and trench collapses (10.3%). These results aid state and local agencies in customizing their presentation of accident data to better fit local regulations and weather conditions, thereby enhancing local safety standards.

title: Estimating construction workers’ physical workload by fusing computer vision and smart insole technologies
authors: Yu, Yantao and Li, Heng and Yang, Xincong and Umer, Waleed
objectives: Construction workers are commonly subjected to ergonomic risks due to awkward postures and/or excessive manual material handling. Accurate ergonomic a
abstract: Construction workers are commonly subjected to ergonomic risks due to awkward postures and/or excessive manual material handling. Accurate ergonomic assessment will facilitate ergonomic risk identification and the subsequent mitigation. Traditional assessment methods such as visual observation and on-body sensors rely on subjective judgement and are intrusive in nature. To cope up with the limitations of the existing technologies, a computer vision and smart insole-based joint-level ergonomic workload calculation methodology is proposed for construction workers. Accordingly, this method could provide an objective and detailed ergonomic assessment for various construction tasks. Firstly, construction workers’ skeleton data is extracted using a smartphone camera with an advanced deep learning algorithm. Secondly, smart insoles are used to quantify the plantar pressures while the worker performs a construction activity. Finally, the gathered data is fed to an inverse dynamic model in order to calculate the joint torques and workloads. The aforementioned approach was tested with experiments comprising simulations of material handling, plastering and rebar. The results reveal that the developed methodology has the potential to provide detailed and accurate ergonomic assessment. Overall, this research contributes to the knowledge of occupational safety and health in construction management by providing a novel approach to assess the risk factors of work-related musculoskeletal disorders (WMSDs). © ISARC 2018 - 35th International Symposium on Automation and Robotics in Construction and International AEC/FM Hackathon: The Future of Building Things. All rights reserved.
Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to develop a novel methodology using computer vision and smart insoles for an objective and detailed ergonomic assessment of construction workers performing various tasks.
Problem: The study addresses the challenge of ergonomic risks among construction workers due to awkward postures and excessive manual material handling, which traditional assessment methods like visual observation and on-body sensors may not evaluate accurately due to their subjective and intrusive nature.
Data: The study utilized skeleton data extracted from construction workers using a smartphone camera fitted with an advanced deep learning algorithm, along with plantar pressure data collected from smart insoles during construction activities.
Methods_Techniques: The methodology involved extracting skeleton data via smartphone cameras, quantifying plantar pressures using smart insoles during tasks, and integrating this data into an inverse dynamic model to calculate joint torques and workloads.
Results: Experiments simulating construction tasks such as material handling, plastering, and rebar installations demonstrated that the developed method provides a detailed and accurate ergonomic assessment, contributing valuable insights to occupational safety and health in construction management.

title: ToolSHeDTM: The development and evaluation of a decision support tool for health and safety in construction design
authors: Cooke, Tracy and Lingard, Helen and Blismas, Nick and Stranieri, Andrew
abstract: Purpose - The purpose of this paper is to describe an innovative information and decision support tool (ToolSHeD™) developed to help construction designers to integrate the management of OHS risk into the design process. The underlying structure of the prototype web-based system and the process of knowledge acquisition and modelling are described. Design/methodology/approach - The ToolSHeD™ research and development project involved the capture of expert reasoning regarding design impacts upon occupational health and safety (OHS) risk. This knowledge was structured using an innovative method well-suited to modelling knowledge in the context of uncertainty and discretionary decision-making. Example "argument trees" are presented, representing the reasoning used by a panel of experts to assess the risk of falling from height during roof maintenance work. The advantage of using this method for modelling OHS knowledge, compared to the use of simplistic rules, is discussed Findings - The ToolSHeD™ prototype development and testing reveals that argument trees can represent design safety risk knowledge effectively. Practical implications - The translation of argument trees into a web-based decision support tool is described and the potential impact of this tool in providing construction designers (architects and engineers) with easy and inexpensive access to expert OHS knowledge is discussed. Originality/value - The paper describes a new computer application, currently undergoing testing in the Australian building and construction industry. Its originality lies in the fact that ToolSHeD™ deploys argument trees to represent expert OHS reasoning, overcoming inherent limitations in rule-based expert systems. © Emerald Group Publishing Limited.
Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to describe ToolSHeD™, an innovative information and decision support tool designed to integrate the management of Occupational Health and Safety (OHS) risk into the construction design process.
Problem: The study addressed the challenge of effectively including OHS risk management within the construction design process, focusing on the need for handling knowledge in contexts characterized by uncertainty and discretionary decision-making.
Data: The data used in this study involved expert reasoning regarding the impact of design choices on OHS risks, particularly in scenarios such as falling from height during roof maintenance work.
Methods_Techniques: The study utilized innovative methods for capturing and structuring expert knowledge, specifically through the development of "argument trees". These argument trees modeled the expert reasoning for assessing OHS risks, which is advantageous over traditional simplistic rule-based systems.
Results: The findings from the development and testing of the ToolSHeD™ prototype indicate that argument trees can effectively represent design safety risk knowledge. The use of these trees in a web-based decision support tool offers potential substantial benefits to construction designers by providing straightforward and cost-effective access to expert OHS knowledge.

title: How harsh work environments affect the occupational accident phenomenology? Risk assessment and decision making optimisation
authors: Murè, Salvina and Comberti, Lorenzo and Demichela, Micaela
abstract: This paper describes a procedure to evaluate the risk of occupational accidents combining SKM (SOM & K-Means) and FAP (Fuzzy Logic approach) to explicitly take into account the impact that harsh productive environments can have on the occupational accident dynamics. The procedure proposed consists of an advanced approach based on two evaluation steps: (1) the investigation of occupational accidents dynamics in a productive sector through the SKM approach, based on neural networks; (2) the occupational accidents risk assessment for a specific plant through the Fuzzy Logic approach, exploiting the knowledge inherent in the accident analysis of an industrial sector to the benefit of the risk assessment in a specific work environment. The application of SKM and FAP approach respectively to the metallurgical sector and to an Italian industrial plant allowed the validation of the proposed procedures. Taking into account the accidents occurred in the Piedmont metallurgical sector from 2006 to 2013, the risk assessment for an Italian steel-manufacturing company was carried on, highlighting how a critical work environment can affect the accident dynamics, and how to correctly take into account their impact during the risk assessment could bring to an effective operational safety improvement. © 2017 Elsevier Ltd
Objectives: The main purpose of this study is to evaluate the risk of occupational accidents by developing a procedural approach that considers the specific impacts of harsh production environments on accident dynamics.
Problem: The challenge addressed is the need for a risk assessment method that effectively incorporates the unique conditions of harsh production environments into occupational accident dynamics evaluations.
Data: The study utilized accident data from the metallurgical sector in Piedmont, covering the years 2006 to 2013.
Methods_Techniques: The study employed two primary methods: the SKM approach, which combines Self-Organizing Maps (SOM) and K-Means clustering and is based on neural networks for analyzing occupational accidents dynamics; and the Fuzzy Logic approach (FAP), used for risk assessments at a specific industrial plant, leveraging accident analysis from a broader industrial sector.
Results: The application of the SKM and FAP methods to the metallurgical sector and an Italian industrial plant, respectively, validated the procedures proposed. Results highlighted how critical work environments impact accident dynamics, and demonstrated that considering these impacts in risk assessments can significantly enhance operational safety.

title: IoT gateway and industrial safety with computer vision
authors: Zubal', M. and Lojka, T. and Zolotová, I.
abstract: Despite of automation and security in plants, industrial environment is still dangerous for humans and machines. This work deals with a safety in industrial condition. We designed and built a system to detect dangerous situations and help to avoid them. In our solution, we created a method to detect dangerous situations. We created safety scenes and situations to verify our algorithms, too. The first algorithm is designed to protect a human. This algorithm detects dangerous collisions of human and thermally dangerous areas. Our algorithm and experiments are based on thermal camera. We created a graphical interface to our method, which allows better configuration for more scenes. Reached result will be implemented in designed IoT gateway, to improve industrial implementation with scalability. © 2016 IEEE.
Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to design and build a system that detects dangerous situations in industrial environments to enhance safety for both humans and machinery.
Problem: The study addressed the ongoing issue of dangerous conditions in industrial settings, despite existing automation and security measures.
Data: The data used in the study were derived from safety scenes and situations specifically created to test and verify the algorithms.
Methods_Techniques: The researchers employed thermal cameras to develop algorithms capable of detecting dangerous collisions involving humans and thermally hazardous areas. They also designed a graphical interface to facilitate better configuration of the system for various scenes.
Results: The main findings established effective algorithms for detecting dangerous situations, which are planned to be integrated into a specially designed IoT gateway to improve scalability and application in industrial settings.

title: Analyzing mine accidents using machine learning
authors: Amoako, R. and Buaba, J. and Brickey, A.
abstract: Over the past three decades, the global mining industry has recorded significant declines in accident and injury rates. This is attributed to advancement in technology, increased enforcement, and safety consciousness (Friedman, Almberg, and Cohen, 2019). Despite these declines, mining remains a high-risk occupation. In 2006, the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) launched the concept of achieving zero injury and occupational illness on mine sites. Researchers have since sought ways to further reduce mine accidents. To this end, we present an alternative means of examining mine accidents and injuries using a machine learning technique known as the multi-class logistic regression. We implement this technique on a ten-year injury data set from the Mine Safety and Health Administration (MSHA) to help identify significant risk factors associated with different classes of injury. Analysis reveals how the following risk factors interact to determine a mine worker's susceptibility to a particular type of injury: experience on the current job, age, sex, employment type, mine type, work location, shift start time, and accident type. Copyright © 2020 by SME
Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to explore alternative methods for examining mine accidents and injuries to contribute to further reducing these incidents.
Problem: Despite significant improvements in accident and injury rates in the mining industry due to advancements in technology, enforcement, and safety awareness, mining still remains a high-risk occupation.
Data: The data used in the study consisted of a ten-year injury dataset provided by the Mine Safety and Health Administration (MSHA).
Methods_Techniques: The study employed a machine learning method known as multi-class logistic regression to analyze the data and identify significant risk factors associated with different classes of injury.
Results: The analysis identified several key risk factors affecting mine workers' susceptibility to injuries, including experience on the current job, age, sex, employment type, mine type, work location, shift start time, and accident type.

title: Virtualized-Fault Injection Testing: A Machine Learning Approach
authors: Khosrowjerdi, Hojat and Meinke, Karl and Rasmusson, Andreas
abstract: We introduce a new methodology for virtualized fault injection testing of safety critical embedded systems. This approach fully automates the key steps of test case generation, fault injection and verdict construction. We use machine learning to reverse engineer models of the system under test. We use model checking to generate test verdicts with respect to safety requirements formalised in temporal logic. We exemplify our approach by implementing a tool chain based on integrating the QEMU hardware emulator, the GNU debugger GDB and the LBTest requirements testing tool. This tool chain is then evaluated on two industrial safety critical applications from the automotive sector. © 2018 IEEE.
Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to introduce a new methodology for virtualized fault injection testing specifically designed for safety-critical embedded systems.
Problem: The challenge addressed was the need for an automated approach to enhance the efficiency and effectiveness of testing safety-critical embedded systems, specifically through automating test case generation, fault injection, and verdict construction.
Data: The study used real data from two industrial safety-critical applications in the automotive sector to evaluate the proposed tool chain.
Methods_Techniques: The methodology employed machine learning to reverse engineer models of the systems under test, and model checking to generate test verdicts based on safety requirements formalized in temporal logic. The researchers implemented a tool chain integrating the QEMU hardware emulator, the GNU debugger GDB, and the LBTest requirements testing tool to exemplify their approach.
Results: The main findings were not detailed in the abstract provided, but the methodology and tool chain were successfully implemented and evaluated using industrial applications, suggesting effectiveness in automating the testing of safety-critical embedded systems.

title: Extraction and Visualization of Occupational Health and Safety Related Information from Open Web
authors: Dasgupta, Tirthankar and Naskar, Abir and Saha, Rupsa and Dey, Lipika
abstract: In this paper, we have proposed natural language processing and deep learning based techniques for the automatic extraction and curation of occupational health and safety related information from safety-related articles. Such articles typically contain details of the organizations that have been cited for violating the health and safety regulations, safety-related issues and incidents, the location of the incident, and finally details of the penalties incurred. We have done experiments with a collection of 5400 related articles. The end-product of our work is an occupational risk-register that contains details of safety incidents across geographies and time. This register can be further utilized for analytical and reporting purposes. Such information is extremely valuable to industries which see a high occurrence of occupational injuries. © 2018 IEEE.
Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to develop natural language processing (NLP) and deep learning techniques for the automatic extraction and curation of occupational health and safety information from safety-related articles.
Problem: The challenge addressed was how to effectively and efficiently process and extract relevant information regarding occupational health and safety violations from a large volume of safety-related articles.
Data: The data used in this study consisted of a collection of 5,400 safety-related articles.
Methods_Techniques: The study applied techniques based on natural language processing and deep learning to automate the extraction and curation of data from the articles.
Results: The main result of the study was the creation of an occupational risk-register, which compiles detailed information on safety incidents across different locations and time periods. This register is intended for further use in analytical and reporting activities, particularly beneficial to industries with high rates of occupational injuries.

title: Evaluation method of coal mine production safety based on BP neural network
authors: Sun, Gang and Zhang, Ruixin and Luo, Fen and Sun, Kelei and Huang, Xiaoming
abstract: Based on the theory of system engineering, coal mine production safety has been analyzed. From workers, production process, coal production and economy, coal mine production safety evaluation indexes have been confirmed, and then the BP neural network model of coal mine production safety evaluation has been built. After training and testing the model, the model can accurately evaluate the coal mine production safety. It is of great guiding significance for coal mine production safety. © 2009 IEEE.
Objectives: The study aimed to evaluate coal mine production safety using a systematic engineering approach.
Problem: The challenge addressed was the need for an effective way to evaluate coal mine production safety considering various factors from workers to economic aspects.
Data: The data consisted of evaluation indexes confirmed across workers, production processes, coal production, and economic parameters related to coal mines.
Methods_Techniques: The study utilized a BP neural network model to evaluate coal mine production safety. This model was trained and tested to ensure its accuracy in safety evaluation.
Results: The main finding was that the BP neural network model effectively evaluates coal mine production safety, offering accurate assessments that could significantly guide improvements in safety standards within the industry.

title: Fuzzy probabilistic expert system for occupational hazard assessment in construction
authors: Amiri, Mehran and Ardeshir, Abdollah and Fazel Zarandi, Mohammad Hossein
problem: Considering the extensive growth of the construction industry in developing countries, the trend of
abstract: Considering the extensive growth of the construction industry in developing countries, the trend of occupational accidents in this sector is growing in recent years. In this regard, developing a hazard management process with a proactive vision makes it possible to identify and prioritize risky points in construction sites and apply preventive measures. Hence, in this paper, a fuzzy probabilistic rule-based expert system is developed for occupational hazard assessment. A fuzzy probabilistic system permits us to model uncertainties related to accident databases and the randomness due to environmental, natural, or time changes. Merging randomness into the occupational risk assessment problem in the construction industry enables the authorities to manage hazards proactively and brings about some practical benefits. The proposed fuzzy probabilistic model benefits from a rule base generated based on fuzzy risk-based statistical and data mining analyses of accident database along with a comprehensive literature review and interviews with experts. This model is tested on four major construction case studies. Through an intensive validation process, the model was successfully analyzed and ranked the risks of different types. The results are encouraging and the model can be implemented in different construction projects. © 2016 Elsevier Ltd
Objectives: The main goal of this study was to develop a hazard management process using a fuzzy probabilistic rule-based expert system for occupational hazard assessment in the construction industry.
Problem: The problem addressed is the growing trend of occupational accidents in the construction industry in developing countries, impacted by the uncertainties related to accident databases and environmental randomness.
Data: The study used data from accident databases, which included statistical and data mining analyses, along with information gathered from a comprehensive literature review and interviews with experts.
Methods_Techniques: The study utilized a fuzzy probabilistic rule-based expert system, which integrates fuzzy logic and probabilistic models to handle uncertainties and randomness. The process also involved generating a rule base from analyses and expert contributions.
Results: The model was successfully tested on four major construction case studies, where it effectively analyzed and ranked different types of risks. The results were positive, indicating that the model can be applied effectively across various construction projects to proactively manage hazards.

title: Evaluating machine learning performance in predicting injury severity in agribusiness industries
authors: Davoudi Kakhki, Fatemeh and Freeman, Steven A. and Mosher, Gretchen A.
objectives: Although machine learning methods have been used as an outcome prediction tool in many fields, their utilization in predicting incident outcome in occ
abstract: Although machine learning methods have been used as an outcome prediction tool in many fields, their utilization in predicting incident outcome in occupational safety is relatively new. This study tests the performance of machine learning techniques in modeling and predicting occupational incidents severity with respect to accessible information of injured workers in agribusiness industries using workers’ compensation claims. More than 33,000 incidents within agribusiness industries in the Midwest of the United States for 2008–2016 were analyzed. The total cost of incidents was extracted and classified from workers’ compensation claims. Supervised machine learning algorithms for classification (support vector machines with linear, quadratic, and RBF kernels, Boosted Trees, and Naïve Bayes) were applied. The models can predict injury severity classification based on injured body part, body group, nature of injury, nature group, cause of injury, cause group, and age and tenure of injured workers with the accuracy rate of 92–98%. The results emphasize the significance of quantitative analysis of empirical injury data in safety science, and contribute to enhanced understanding of injury patterns using predictive modeling along with safety experts’ perspectives with regulatory or managerial viewpoints. The predictive models obtained from this study can be used to augment the experience of safety professionals in agribusiness industries to improve safety intervention efforts. © 2019 The Authors
Objectives: The main goal of this study was to test the performance of machine learning techniques in predicting the severity of occupational incidents in agribusiness industries based on accessible information of injured workers.
Problem: The challenge addressed in this study is the relatively novel application of machine learning methods in predicting incident outcomes specifically within the realm of occupational safety.
Data: The data used in this study comprised over 33,000 occupational incidents from agribusiness industries in the Midwest of the United States, spanning from 2008 to 2016. This data, including the total cost of incidents, was sourced from workers’ compensation claims.
Methods_Techniques: The study employed supervised machine learning algorithms for classification, including support vector machines with linear, quadratic, and RBF kernels, Boosted Trees, and Naïve Bayes, to model and predict the severity of incidents.
Results: The study found that the machine learning models achieved an accuracy rate of 92–98% in predicting injury severity classification. These models used various predictors such as the injured body part, nature of injury, cause of injury, and the age and tenure of injured workers. The results underscore the importance of quantitative analysis of empirical data in safety science and demonstrate how predictive modeling can enhance the understanding of injury patterns and support safety intervention efforts in agribusiness industries.

title: Development of the EHS management system as SaaS for small and medium manufacturing firms
authors: Seo, Kwang-Kyu and Yoon, S.
abstract: Manufacturing firms are facing potential environment, health and safety (EHS) issues of major accidents to cause casualties or a financial loss and increasing social responsibility. Therefore they have to voluntarily accomplish the EHS management system rather than passively with regard to the EHS regulation. In this study, we develop the cloud computing service based EHS management system as SaaS for small and medium manufacturing firms to materialize self-regulation EHS process of manufacturing workplace and to standardize and visualize the EHS business process. The proposed system also provides risk analysis, education/control and continuous improvement for EHS tasks and users can easily access the system on the web at a low price through cloud computing service. Eventually, the proposed cloud computing service based EHS management system as SaaS contributes to the managerial improvement by minimizing economic and physical loss caused by EHS accidents and can be easily integrated into legacy systems such as ERP. © 2012 AICIT.
Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to develop a cloud computing service-based Environment, Health, and Safety (EHS) management system as Software as a Service (SaaS) specifically tailored for small and medium manufacturing firms. This system aims to facilitate self-regulation of EHS processes in the manufacturing environment and to standardize and visualize EHS business processes.
Problem: The study addresses the challenge manufacturing firms face in managing potential environment, health, and safety issues such as major accidents that could lead to casualties or significant financial loss. The increasing demand for corporate social responsibility also pressures firms to move beyond mere compliance with EHS regulations towards proactive engagement in EHS management.
Data: The abstract does not specify the data used in the study.
Methods_Techniques: The method involved developing an EHS management system leveraging cloud computing to deliver the service as SaaS. This system was designed to include features such as risk analysis, education/control mechanisms, and continuous improvement capabilities for EHS tasks, accessible via the web at an affordable price.
Results: The cloud-based EHS management system was found to contribute to managerial improvements by minimizing economic and physical losses due to EHS accidents. Additionally, it is easily integrable with legacy systems such as Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) systems, enhancing its usability within existing corporate infrastructures.

title: Severity of U.S. Construction Worker Injuries, 2015-2017
authors: Passmore, David and Chae, Chungil and Borkovskaya, Victoria and Baker, Rose and Yim, Jeong-Ha
abstract: Workers in the U.S. construction industry experience workplace hazards that can lead to work-related injuries that sometimes are fatal. Reported in this paper is a case-control study of risks factors associated with 4,845 injured workers and their work environments that led to fatal rather than nonfatal injuries during 2015-2017. These injury data originally were assembled from information collected by the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics that were used in a machine learning competition, but were repurposed for this secondary analysis of injury risks. Sixty-one percent of workers recorded in this dataset were injured fatally. Multiple logistic regression was applied to model the probability of a fatal injury as a function of the nature of the injury, part of body injured, human factors involved, whether the injured worker was carrying out a regularly assigned task at the time of the injury, and the manner in which the injury was inflicted. Related positively, relative to benchmarks, to the probability of a fatality injury were: falls and strikes; electrocution; asphyxiation and drowning; injury to the head and neck; and working at a task not regularly assigned. Negatively related to the probability of a fatal injury were: chemical/temperature burns; amputation and crushing; fractures and dislocations; injuries to fingers, hands, wrists, and other extremities; and falls from an elevation or to the same level, although this last negative relationship is anomalous in the light of independent research findings. Findings of this study do not necessarily culpable causes of work-related death. Rather these findings identify risk factors that might prove fruitful for further analysis of the incidence, severity, and costs of construction injuries. © The Authors, published by EDP Sciences, 2019.
Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to identify risk factors associated with fatal injuries versus nonfatal injuries among workers in the U.S. construction industry during the years 2015-2017.
Problem: The study addressed the challenge of understanding what factors contribute to fatal injuries in the construction industry to help in risk reduction and improve workplace safety.
Data: The data utilized in the study consisted of injury reports for 4,845 workers collected by the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, originally used for a machine learning competition and repurposed for this analysis.
Methods_Techniques: The study applied multiple logistic regression to model the probability of a fatal injury based on various factors such as the nature of the injury, the body part injured, human factors involved, whether the task during the injury was regularly assigned, and the manner of injury infliction.
Results: The results indicated that fatal injuries were positively related to falls, strikes, electrocution, asphyxiation, drowning, and injuries to the head and neck. Conversely, nonfatal injuries were more commonly associated with chemical or temperature burns, amputations, crushing, fractures, dislocations, and injuries to extremities. The finding that falls from an elevation were negatively related to fatality was noted as anomalous compared to other research.

title: An adaptive neuro-fuzzy inference system (anfis) model for assessing occupational risk in the shipbuilding industry
authors: Fragiadakis, N.G. and Tsoukalas, V.D. and Papazoglou, V.J.
abstract: In this research an adaptive neuro-fuzzy inference system (ANFIS) has been applied to study the effect of working conditions on occupational injury using data of professional accidents assembled by ship repair yards. The data were statistically processed in order to select the most important parameters. These parameters were day and time, specialty, type of incident, dangerous situations and dangerous actions involved in the incident. The selected parameters proved, due to statistical processing, to be correlated to the observed frequency of four injury categories, namely negligible wounding, slight wounding, severe wounding and death. For each parameter a Gravity Factor (GF) was calculated based on the percentage of injury categories resulting to the incident each of the above mentioned parameter was involved. These GF values and the resulting risk value based on the accident data were used as input values to train the ANFIS model. Trapezoidal and Gauss membership functions were used for the training of the data. The model combined the modeling function of fuzzy inference with the learning ability of artificial neural networks. A set of rules has been generated directly from the statistically processed reported data. The model's predictions were compared with a number of recorded data for verifying the approach. © 2013 Elsevier Ltd.
Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to apply an adaptive neuro-fuzzy inference system (ANFIS) to evaluate the impact of working conditions on occupational injuries in ship repair yards.
Problem: The study addressed the challenge of understanding how different factors contribute to the frequency and severity of occupational injuries in the context of ship repair work environments.
Data: The data utilized in this study consisted of records on professional accidents collected by ship repair yards. Key parameters included day and time, specialty, type of incident, and details on dangerous situations and actions involved in each incident.
Methods_Techniques: The study involved statistical processing of data to identify significant parameters correlated with injury frequency in four categories (negligible wounding, slight wounding, severe wounding, and death). Gravity Factor (GF) values were computed for these parameters based on their percentage contribution to injuries. These GF values, along with risk values derived from accident data, served as inputs for training the ANFIS model. The model training used trapezoidal and Gauss membership functions, combining fuzzy inference and neural network learning capabilities to generate a set of rules based on the data.
Results: The ANFIS model was able to predict occupational injuries and their associations with different working conditions at ship repair yards. The predictions were verified against recorded data, validating the effectiveness of the approach.

title: Risk Assessment of Hypertension in Steel Workers Based on LVQ and Fisher-SVM Deep Excavation
authors: Wu, Jian-Hui and Wei, Wei and Zhang, Lu and Wang, Jie and Damasevicius, Robertas and Li, Jing and Wang, Hai-Dong and Wang, Guo-Li and Zhang, Xin and Yuan, Ju-Xiang and Wozniak, Marcin
abstract: The steel industry is one of the pillar industries in China. The physical and mental health of steel workers is related to the development of China's steel industry. Steel workers have long been working in shifts, high temperatures, noise, highly stressed, and first-line environments. These occupational related factors have an impact on the health of steel workers. At present, the existing hypertension risk scoring models do not include occupational related factors, so they are not applicable to the risk score of hypertension in steel workers. It is necessary to establish a risk scoring model for hypertension in steel workers. In this study, the learning vector quantization (LVQ) neural network algorithm and the Fisher-SVM coupling algorithm are applied to estimate the hypertension risk of steel workers, and the microscopic laws of the 'tailing' phenomenon of the two algorithms are analyzed by means of graphics analysis, which can describe the influence trend of sample size change in different intervals on the classification effect. The results show that the classification accuracy of the algorithm depends on the size of the sample space. When the sample size n ≤ 30 ∗ (k + 1), the Fisher-SVM coupling intelligent algorithm is more applicable. Because its average accuracy rate is 90.00%, the average accuracy of the LVQ algorithm is only 63.34%. When the sample size is n > 30 ∗ (k + 1), the LVQ algorithm is more applicable. Because its average accuracy rate is 93.33%, the average accuracy of the Fisher-SVM coupling intelligent algorithm is only 76.67%. The sample size of this paper is 4422, and the prediction of LVQ neural network model is more accurate. Therefore, based on the relative importance of each risk factor obtained by this model and to establish a steel worker hypertension risk rating scale, the score greater than 18 is considered as the high risk, 12-18 is considered as the medium risk, and less than 12 is considered as the low risk. Through the example's verification, the accuracy rate of the scale is 90.50% and the effect is very good. It shows that the established scoring system can effectively assess the risk of hypertension in steel workers and provide an effective basis for primary prevention of hypertension in steel workers. © 2013 IEEE.
Objectives: The main purpose of this study is to establish a risk scoring model specifically designed to assess the risk of hypertension in steel workers, taking into account occupational factors that affect their health.
Problem: The existing hypertension risk scoring models do not include occupational factors relevant to steel workers, making them unsuitable for accurately assessing hypertension risk in this demographic.
Data: The study utilized a sample size of 4422 steel workers to conduct the analysis and build the appropriate risk scoring model.
Methods_Techniques: The study applied the learning vector quantization (LVQ) neural network algorithm and the Fisher-SVM coupling algorithm to estimate hypertension risk. Additionally, graphical analysis was used to explore the 'tailing' phenomenon of both algorithms, observing how changes in sample size within different intervals impact classification effectiveness.
Results: The results revealed that the model’s classification accuracy varies with the size of the sample space. When the sample size is less than or equal to 30 times (k+1), the Fisher-SVM algorithm proved more suitable with an average accuracy rate of 90.00%. In contrast, for sample sizes larger than 30 times (k+1), the LVQ algorithm was more appropriate, exhibiting an average accuracy rate of 93.33%. The LVQ neural network model demonstrated superior prediction accuracy in this study with a sample size of 4422. Based on this model, a risk rating scale for hypertension in steel workers was established with three risk categories, and this scoring system showed an accuracy rate of 90.50%, indicating its effectiveness in assessing hypertension risk among steel workers.

title: Severity Prediction Models of Falling Risk for Workers at Height
authors: Chen, Hainan and Luo, Xiaowei
abstract: Construction industry has one of the highest accident and fatality rates among other major industries, with more than 60,000 fatal accidents each year worldwide. Falling from height is one of the leading causes of fatalities and injuries in construction. Passive protection devices (e.g., safety net) have been used to minimize the impact of falling from height for ages, while proactive warning systems appear recently to alert the workers when they are at risks of falling. To provide appropriate warnings to the worker but not to distract them due to the false alarm, the falling risk needs to be carefully evaluated. In this paper, the authors introduced algorithms for falling risk prediction and evaluated their performance. Injuries records during 2005 to 2015 were extracted from the OSHA database and 1161 intact falling-related record were used in this study. K-Modes, RBF network and Decision Trees are chosen to build three risk prediction models, and the performance of those three proposed models were evaluated using the OSHA injuries record data. The results indicate that the DT-based falling risk prediction model has the best performance of 75% and the top three critical factors of falling event's severity are distance from the ground, worker's occupation and the source of the falling. The delivered severity prediction model provides the foundation of more accurate real time risk evaluation for workers at height. © 2016 The Authors. Published by Elsevier Ltd.
Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to introduce and evaluate algorithms for falling risk prediction to enhance the warning systems in construction sites, thereby reducing the risk of falling from heights.
Problem: The construction industry faces a high rate of accidents and fatalities, particularly from falls from height. Current passive protection measures are not sufficient, and there is a need for effective proactive warning systems that minimize false alarms while accurately assessing falling risks.
Data: The study utilized injury records from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) database, specifically examining 1,161 intact falling-related records from the years 2005 to 2015.
Methods_Techniques: The researchers developed three risk prediction models using different algorithms: K-Modes, Radial Basis Function (RBF) network, and Decision Trees (DT). They then evaluated the performance of these models using the OSHA injuries record data.
Results: The Decision Tree-based model was found to be the most effective, with a performance accuracy of 75%. The study also identified the top three critical factors influencing the severity of falling events as the distance from the ground, the worker's occupation, and the source of the fall. These insights aid in better real-time risk evaluation for workers at heights.

title: Intelligent monitoring system for improved: Worker safety during plant operation and maintenance
authors: Parks, D. and McNinch, M. and Jacksha, R. and Nickerson, H. and Miller, A.
abstract: A wireless IoT system was utilized to monitor a LOTO process and shows hope for both making LOTO less burdensome and providing additional accountability for following required safety practices. NIOSH researchers are currently expanding this system, in terms of scope and functionality. The final system is expected to include predictive failure analysis as well as additional sensors to monitor worker proximity to hazards. Significant research will be conducted in the field human factors in hopes of ensuring that the system is easy to use and effective, thereby encouraging widespread adoption throughout the mining industry. The proliferation of IoT devices, in the business and consumer spheres, illustrates that the public is ready to adopt these new solutions. The mining sector in particular will benefit enormously from the ability to remotely view safety-related data in real time and to receive alarms when safeguards are potentially failing. There is a preponderance of evidence that conveyor operation and maintenance is hazardous to workers, and NIOSH will continue working to reduce these accidents through leveraging emerging technologies such as IoT. © 2019 Society for Mining, Metallurgy and Exploration. All rights reserved.
Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to enhance the Lockout/Tagout (LOTO) process using a wireless IoT system to make it less burdensome and to increase accountability for safety practices adherence, particularly in the mining industry.
Problem: The challenge addressed in this study involves reducing the hazards associated with conveyor operation and maintenance in the mining sector, where traditional safety measures have so far been insufficient.
Data: Not explicitly mentioned in the abstract.
Methods_Techniques: The researchers employed an expanding wireless IoT system that includes predictive failure analysis and additional sensors for monitoring worker proximity to hazards. The study also focuses on human factors research to ensure the system's ease of use and effectiveness to encourage wider adoption.
Results: The study shows promising results in making LOTO processes less burdensome and in providing additional accountability through the deployment of advanced IoT technologies. The potential for real-time safety data monitoring and alarm systems is also highlighted as beneficial for improving safety standards in the mining industry.

title: Automated ergonomic risk monitoring using body-mounted sensors and machine learning
authors: Nath, Nipun D. and Chaspari, Theodora and Behzadan, Amir H.
abstract: Workers in various industries are often subject to challenging physical motions that may lead to work-related musculoskeletal disorders (WMSDs). To prevent WMSDs, health and safety organizations have established rules and guidelines that regulate duration and frequency of labor-intensive activities. In this paper, a methodology is introduced to unobtrusively evaluate the ergonomic risk levels caused by overexertion. This is achieved by collecting time-stamped motion data from body-mounted smartphones (i.e., accelerometer, linear accelerometer, and gyroscope signals), automatically detecting workers’ activities through a classification framework, and estimating activity duration and frequency information. This study also investigates various data acquisition and processing settings (e.g., smartphone's position, calibration, window size, and feature types) through a leave-one-subject-out cross-validation framework. Results indicate that signals collected from arm-mounted smartphone device, when calibrated, can yield accuracy up to 90.2% in the considered 3-class classification task. Further post-processing the output of activity classification yields very accurate estimation of the corresponding ergonomic risk levels. This work contributes to the body of knowledge by expanding the current state in workplace health assessment by designing and testing ubiquitous wearable technology to improve the timeliness and quality of ergonomic-related data collection and analysis. © 2018 Elsevier Ltd
Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to unobtrusively evaluate ergonomic risk levels caused by overexertion in the workplace using smartphone-based motion detection technology.
Problem: The problem addressed was the need to prevent work-related musculoskeletal disorders (WMSDs) by monitoring the physical motions of workers that could lead to such health issues.
Data: The data utilized in the study included time-stamped motion data collected from body-mounted smartphones, specifically capturing accelerometer, linear accelerometer, and gyroscope signals.
Methods_Techniques: The study implemented a methodology involving the automatic detection of workers' activities through a classification framework and estimating the duration and frequency of these activities. Data acquisition and processing settings, like smartphone position, calibration, window size, and types of features, were explored using a leave-one-subject-out cross-validation framework.
Results: The findings showed that arm-mounted smartphones, when calibrated, can achieve up to 90.2% accuracy in a 3-class classification task of detecting worker activities. Additionally, post-processing of classification outputs provided highly accurate estimations of corresponding ergonomic risk levels.

title: Applying data mining techniques to analyze the causes of major occupational accidents in the petrochemical industry
authors: Cheng, Ching-Wu and Yao, Hong-Qing and Wu, Tsung-Chih
problem: Accidents that occur in the petrochemical industry frequently result in serious social issues. Behin
abstract: Accidents that occur in the petrochemical industry frequently result in serious social issues. Behind every occupational accident, there are safety management problems requiring investigation. This study collected 349 cases of major occupational accidents in the petrochemical industry between 2000 and 2010 in Taiwan for analysis. Using descriptive statistics, we elucidated the factor distribution of these major occupational accidents. The data mining classification and regression tree (CART) was used to examine the distribution and rules governing the factors of the disasters. This study found that for equipment such as pipelines and control valves, devising high-quality safety and protective devices/ maintenance/renewal plans and pipeline setups/design plans can effectively prevent accidents such as fires, explosions, and poisoning caused by material leakage, as well as employees being caught in/rolled up in machinery. Furthermore, implementing safety management measures, such as worker safety educational training, and enforcing standards for inspections, operations, and risk assessments personnel, has become an important factor in accident prevention. This study suggests the use of the following measures: for abnormal conditions such as pipeline cracking/damage or rusting, hightemperatures caused by material leakage into the inner protective layer of pipelines should be prevented. Considering overlapping pipelines, rusting issues caused by pipelines touching each other should be avoided, and maintenance and repair should be performed to ensure the safety of work environments. These measures can eliminate the risk of work injuries and resulting social issues. © 2013 Elsevier Ltd.
Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to analyze and identify preventive measures for major occupational accidents in the petrochemical industry in Taiwan.
Problem: The study addressed the challenge of frequent accidents in the petrochemical industry, which often result in serious social issues and are primarily caused by underlying safety management issues.
Data: The study utilized a dataset of 349 cases of major occupational accidents that occurred in the petrochemical industry in Taiwan between the years 2000 and 2010.
Methods_Techniques: Descriptive statistics were employed to outline the factor distribution of the occupational accidents. The classification and regression tree (CART) data mining technique was utilized to examine the distribution and determine the rules governing the contributing factors to these accidents.
Results: The findings indicated that implementing high-quality safety devices, maintenance plans, and proper pipeline and design setups can significantly reduce the risk of fires, explosions, and poisoning due to material leakage, as well as accidents involving machinery entanglement. Moreover, safety management measures like worker safety training, inspections, operation standards, and risk assessments were highlighted as crucial for preventing accidents. Recommendations were made to address specific risks such as pipeline damage and rusting to ensure the safety of work environments and prevent occupational accidents and their ensuing social issues.

title: Finding occupational accident patterns in the extractive industry using a systematic data mining approach
authors: Silva, Joaquim F. and Jacinto, Celeste
abstract: This paper deals with occupational accident patterns of in the Portuguese Extractive Industry. It constitutes a significant advance with relation to a previous study made in 2008, both in terms of methodology and extended knowledge on the patterns' details. This work uses more recent data (2005-2007) and this time the identification of the typical accident shifts from a bivariate, to a multivariate pattern, for characterising more accurately the accident mechanisms. Instead of crossing only two variables (Deviation x Contact), the new methodology developed here uses data mining techniques to associate nine variables, through their categories, and to quantify the statistical cohesion of each pattern. The results confirmed the typical accident of the 2008 study, but went much further: it reveals three statistically significant patterns (the top-3 categories in frequency); moreover, each pattern includes now more variables (4-5 categories) and indicates their statistical cohesion. This approach allowed a more accurate vision of the reality, which is fundamental for risk management. The methodology is best suited for large groups, such as national Authorities, Insurers or Corporate Groups, to assist them planning target-oriented safety strategies. Not least importantly, researchers can apply the same algorithm to other study areas, as it is not restricted to accidents, neither to safety. © 2012 Elsevier Ltd.
Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to improve understanding of occupational accident patterns in the Portuguese Extractive Industry by refining the methodology used in previous studies and expanding knowledge on accident patterns.
Problem: The challenge addressed was the limited scope of a previous study (2008) that used a simpler, bivariate analysis for identifying accident patterns, which needed enhancement to more accurately characterize accident mechanisms.
Data: The study utilized more recent occupational accident data collected from the years 2005 to 2007 in the Portuguese Extractive Industry.
Methods_Techniques: This study advanced from a bivariate analysis to a multivariate pattern analysis using data mining techniques. It involved associating nine variables and quantifying the statistical cohesion among these variables to identify distinct accident patterns.
Results: The study not only confirmed the typical accident pattern identified in the 2008 study but also discovered three statistically significant new patterns. These patterns involved 4-5 categories of variables and provided a measure of their statistical cohesion. This enriched approach offered a more precise view of the accident scenarios, which is crucial for effective risk management.

title: Use of soft computing methods in risk assessment of electrostatic fire and explosion hazards in industries
authors: Berta, István
problem: The general problem in the theoretical and practical examination of hazards coming into existence in
abstract: The general problem in the theoretical and practical examination of hazards coming into existence in case of real, complicated industrial systems is basically the approximation of complicated multivariable functions of input and output variables. There is a rather new tool for solving the aforesaid problem, namely the use of soft computing methods: fuzzy logic, artificial neural networks and genetic algorithms. The new approaches can be effectively used for both the risk evaluation of working systems (checking and auditing) and-by using the predictive power of the methods-for designing and planning activities in industrial electrostatics. © 2009 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to explore the use of soft computing methods such as fuzzy logic, artificial neural networks, and genetic algorithms for risk evaluation and predictive analysis in industrial electrostatic systems.
Problem: The study addressed the complexity of approximating multivariable functions in the context of real, complicated industrial systems, and how traditional methods may fall short in effectively addressing these challenges.
Data: The abstract does not explicitly mention the specific data used in the study.
Methods_Techniques: The study applied soft computing methods, specifically fuzzy logic, artificial neural networks, and genetic algorithms, to evaluate risks and conduct predictive analysis in industrial electrostatics.
Results: The main findings suggested that these new approaches are effective for risk evaluation in operational systems (through checking and auditing) and can also be utilized in the planning and design stages using their predictive capabilities.

title: Notice of Retraction: The construction of industrial safety evaluation index system under the background of globalization
authors: He, Wei-Da and Zhang, Kai
abstract: Under the background of globalization, the basic function of resource supply and ecological environment is becoming more and more for the sustainable development of the industry itself, and its impact on the industry's own safety as much as other economic activities. In this paper, the influences of resource supply and ecological environment are discussed for industrial safety based on review of the evaluation index system, and the industrial safety evaluation index system was constructed from social safety, economic security and ecological security. At last, the related issues of industrial safety are discussed. © 2011 IEEE.
Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to discuss and analyze the influences of resource supply and ecological environment on industrial safety.
Problem: The challenge addressed was the increasing importance of resource supply and ecological environment for the sustainable development and safety of industries in the context of globalization.
Data: The study reviewed existing evaluation index systems related to industrial safety.
Methods_Techniques: The method involved constructing an industrial safety evaluation index system focusing on social safety, economic security, and ecological security.
Results: The main finding was the establishment of a comprehensive evaluation index system for industrial safety, which highlights the interdependence of social, economic, and ecological factors.

title: Safety performance evaluation models: A review
authors: Adebiyi, K.A. and Charles-Owaba, O.E. and Waheed, M.A.
objectives: Purpose – Managing a safety programme and ensuring that change is in accordance with suitable performance measures requires continuing improvement in
abstract: Purpose – Managing a safety programme and ensuring that change is in accordance with suitable performance measures requires continuing improvement in the support of analytical power and empirical information. This paper aims to consider different approaches and modeling efforts on safety performance evaluation. Design/methodology/approach – Review and synthesis of literature. Findings – Ten major safety performance evaluation approaches are identified including expectation function, risk assessment, statistical quality control, price deflation, engineering economic factor, system analysis, artificial intelligence, and systems theory. Based on the approaches, quantitative and qualitative models have been proposed. The quantitative models use measuring indicators such as frequency, severity, percentages, relative weight and economic gains/loss of safety programme. However, qualitative models employ hazard analysis and hazard operability. Research limitations/implications – Several research questions remain to be answered in order to completely improve and optimize the impact of these provisional safety performance measures. Originality/value – This study offers a set of interesting lessons for academics, industry and safety practitioners by providing guidelines that will assist in ensuring a correct focus to select an appropriate safety performance evaluation model. © 2007, Emerald Group Publishing Limited
Objectives: The main purpose of the study was to review various approaches and modeling efforts used in safety performance evaluation.
Problem: The study addressed the challenge of managing safety programs effectively and aligning them with suitable performance measures to facilitate continuous improvement.
Data: The study utilized data from a review and synthesis of existing literature related to safety performance evaluation.
Methods_Techniques: The study employed a literature review methodology to identify and synthesize different modeling and evaluation approaches in safety performance.
Results: The main findings of the study included the identification of ten major safety performance evaluation approaches such as expectation function, risk assessment, statistical quality control, price deflation, engineering economic factor, system analysis, artificial intelligence, and systems theory. Both quantitative and qualitative models were proposed, where quantitative models use indicators like frequency, severity, and economic impacts, and qualitative models involve hazard analysis and operability studies.

title: Intelligent systems for HAZOP analysis of complex process plants
authors: Venkatasubramanian, Venkat and Zhao, Jinsong and Viswanathan, Shankar
abstract: Process safety, occupational health and environmental issues are ever increasing in importance in response to heightening public concerns and the resultant tightening of regulations. The process industries are addressing these concerns with a systematic and thorough process hazards analysis (PHA) of their new, as well as existing facilities. Given the enormous amounts of time, effort and money involved in performing the PHA reviews, there exists considerable incentive for automating the process hazards analysis of chemical process plants. In this paper, we review the progress in this area over the past few years. We also discuss the progress that has been made in our laboratory on the industrial application of intelligent systems for operating procedure synthesis and HAZOP analysis. Recent advances in this area have promising implications for process hazards analysis, inherently safer design, operator training and real-time fault diagnosis.
