The process industries are addressing these concerns with a systematic and thorough process hazards analysis (PHA) of their new, as well as existing facilities. Given the enormous amounts of time, effort and money involved in performing the PHA reviews, there exists considerable incentive for automating the process hazards analysis of chemical process plants. In this paper, we review the progress in this area over the past few years. We also discuss the progress that has been made in our laboratory on the industrial application of intelligent systems for operating procedure synthesis and HAZOP analysis. Recent advances in this area have promising implications for process hazards analysis, inherently safer design, operator training and real-time fault diagnosis.
Objectives: The main purpose of this study is to explore the automation of process hazards analysis (PHA) in chemical process industries, and examine the application of intelligent systems within this context.
Problem: The study addresses the challenges faced by the chemical process industries in conducting PHA due to the substantial amounts of time, effort, and financial resources required, heightened by increasing public concerns and stringent regulations.
Data: The abstract does not specify the exact data used; however, it references reviews and discussions on progress made in the field and in specific laboratory studies.
Methods_Techniques: The methods discussed include the development and application of intelligent systems for synthesizing operating procedures and conducting Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) analysis within the industrial setting.
Results: The study finds that recent advances in intelligent systems offer promising outcomes for improving process hazards analysis, inherently safer design, operator training, and real-time fault diagnosis in the chemical process industries.

title: Data mining mine safety data
authors: Dessureault, S. and Sinuhaji, A. and Coleman, P.
abstract: The U.S. Mine Safety and Heath Administration (MSHA) developed a mine accident database from Part 50 of the Federal mine safety regulations. This database is a valuable resource for keeping track of the numbers, rates and severity of mine accidents in the United States. Epidemiologists and mine safety researchers have used it to perform many analyses, helping to guide research and bestpractices. Database technology has changed from when the database was originally designed in the early 1980s. Contemporary analytic databases, typically called data warehouses, focus on table structure to facilitate integrating many different data sources for the purpose of applying analysis and visualization tools to gain more in-depth knowledge. In early 2006, the U.S. National Institute for Occupational Health and Safety (NIOSH) funded an exploratory research project to evaluate the potential benefits of reengineering the MSHA Part 50 data into a data warehouse environment and to assess the potential of data mining to give new insight. This paper explores the background of the Part 50 database, gives a general background of data warehousing and data mining, and presents some of the interesting analyses that resulted from a modernized Part 50 data warehouse using data mining.
Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to evaluate the potential benefits of reengineering the Mine Safety and Heath Administration's (MSHA) Part 50 accident database into a data warehouse environment and assess the potential of data mining techniques for gaining new insights.
Problem: The primary challenge addressed was the outdated technology of the original MSHA Part 50 database and the need to integrate it with modern data analysis and visualization tools to improve mine safety research.
Data: The study utilized the MSHA Part 50 accident database, which contains records of mine accidents, including numbers, rates, and severity from the U.S. mining industry.
Methods_Techniques: The methods applied in the study included the transformation of the existing database into a data warehouse format and the application of data mining techniques to analyze the data more effectively.
Results: The reengineering of the database allowed for more in-depth analysis through data mining, which provided new insights into mine safety that can guide future research and improvements in best practices.

title: Evaluation of an artificial intelligence program for estimating occupational exposures
authors: Johnston, Karen L. and Phillips, Margaret L. and Esmen, Nurtan A. and Hall, Thomas A.
abstract: Estimation and Assessment of Substance Exposure (EASE) is an artificial intelligence program developed by UK's Health and Safety Executive to assess exposure. EASE computes estimated airborne concentrations based on a substance's vapor pressure and the types of controls in the work area. Though EASE is intended only to make broad predictions of exposure from occupational environments, some occupational hygienists might attempt to use EASE for individual exposure characterizations. This study investigated whether EASE would accurately predict actual sampling results from a chemical manufacturing process. Personal breathing zone time-weighted average (TWA) monitoring data for two volatile organic chemicals-a common solvent (toluene) and a specialty monomer (chloroprene)-present in this manufacturing process were compared to EASE-generated estimates. EASE-estimated concentrations for specific tasks were weighted by task durations reported in the monitoring record to yield TWA estimates from EASE that could be directly compared to the measured TWA data. Two hundred and six chloroprene and toluene full-shift personal samples were selected from eight areas of this manufacturing process. The Spearman correlation between EASE TWA estimates and measured TWA values was 0.55 for chloroprene and 0.44 for toluene, indicating moderate predictive values for both compounds. For toluene, the interquartile range of EASE estimates at least partially overlapped the interquartile range of the measured data distributions in all process areas. The interquartile range of EASE estimates for chloroprene fell above the interquartile range of the measured data distributions in one process area, partially overlapped the third quartile of the measured data in five process areas and fell within the interquartile range in two process areas. EASE is not a substitute for actual exposure monitoring. However, EASE can be used in conditions that cannot otherwise be sampled and in preliminary exposure assessment if it is recognized that the actual interquartile range could be much wider and/or offset by a factor of 10 or more. © 2004 British Occupational Hygiene Society.
Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to investigate whether the Estimation and Assessment of Substance Exposure (EASE) artificial intelligence program could accurately predict actual sampling results of airborne concentrations of specific chemicals in a chemical manufacturing process.
Problem: The problem addressed in this study is that while EASE is designed to make general predictions of occupational environmental exposure, it was unclear if it could accurately determine individual exposure characterizations for specific tasks in real-world settings.
Data: The data used in the study included personal breathing zone time-weighted average (TWA) monitoring data for two volatile organic chemicals—toluene and chloroprene—from a chemical manufacturing process. Specifically, two hundred and six full-shift personal samples of chloroprene and toluene collected from eight different areas within the manufacturing process were utilized.
Methods_Techniques: The study involved comparing the TWA estimates generated by EASE, which were weighted by task durations as reported in monitoring records, with the measured TWA data. The Spearman correlation coefficient was used to assess the relationship between the EASE-generated estimates and the actual measured values.
Results: The results demonstrated moderate predictive accuracy of EASE, with Spearman correlation coefficients of 0.55 for chloroprene and 0.44 for toluene. While the interquartile range of EASE estimates for toluene partially overlapped with the interquartile range of the measured data across all process areas, the EASE estimates for chloroprene were less consistent and varied more across different process areas. The study concluded that EASE should not replace actual exposure monitoring but could still serve useful in preliminary exposure assessments and in scenarios where direct sampling is not feasible.

title: CBR research using the 'think', 'plan', 'do' classification method
authors: Campbell, Jennifer M. and Smith, Simon D.
abstract: Recent skill shortages in the UK Construction Industry have undoubtedly lead to a loss of tacit knowledge and experience. In addition, clients' need for greater value and better construction services results in companies striving for competitive advantage by becoming more efficient in the way they manage their knowledge systems and resources. Although Case-based reasoning (CBR) originated in artificial intelligence research, it has transcended barriers between technology and methodology to become applicable in many industrial and research fields. Research and applications have shown CBR can emulate human reasoning and decision making processes and as such a wide variety of construction tasks have been used in case studies. Furthermore, CBR applications may cover many areas of a project life cycle, but the extent of coverage was generally unknown. By mapping an innovative three-stage classification method to the accepted model of a project life cycle, past CBR research can be grouped and inspected. This 'think', 'plan, and 'do' classification method has shown imbalance of CBR research applications within the construction industry with little aid to those involved in the 'doing' phases. The 'think', 'plan', 'do' classification method has identified potential areas where the further application of CBR may prove useful within infrastructure management, and in particular within an educational role for safety and risk management.
Objectives: The main purpose of this study was to explore how Case-based Reasoning (CBR) could be effectively mapped across different stages of the project life cycle in the construction industry to improve knowledge management and decision-making processes.
Problem: The study addresses the challenge of skill shortages and loss of tacit knowledge in the UK Construction Industry, alongside the need for companies to enhance efficiency and gain competitive advantage by better managing their knowledge systems.
Data: The data used comprised past research and applications of CBR in various construction tasks, evaluated within the framework of the project life cycle stages.
Methods_Techniques: The study employed a novel three-stage classification method ('think', 'plan', 'do') mapped to the conventional model of a project life cycle to organize and assess past CBR research within the construction industry.
Results: The findings revealed an imbalance in CBR research applications across different phases of construction projects, particularly under-serving the 'doing' phases. Additionally, it identified potential areas where CBR could be further applied, especially within infrastructure management and educational roles focused on safety and risk management.
